name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the annual strategic report of Eleni Theocharous and Francesc Gambaus, on behalf of the Committee on Development and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security, on the implementation and achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) (2018/2279 (INI)) (A8-0160/2019).

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, we want the voice of the European Parliament to be heard loud at a time when multilateral cooperation for the well-being of people and for the good of the planet, both in the context of actions on climate change and for solidarity and peace, cannot be taken for granted.  It is therefore important to continue the practice of the annual strategy report on the implementation and implementation of the sustainable development objectives and to represent the European Parliament every year in the high-level political forum. Today, the strategy report is all the more timely given that the Commission is preparing the joint synthesis report, which we expect shortly, on the European Union's support for developing countries in the implementation of the 2030 agenda, with the contribution of the Member States of the European Union as well. We are convinced that a truly multi-level governance approach with active involvement of the public, civil society and the private sector is needed on a broad basis for the effective implementation of sustainable development objectives. Close monitoring, proportionate accountability and effective review mechanisms assessing progress made are essential for improving national strategies and effectively implementing targets at all levels.  Our report aims to contribute to the preparation of the European Union for a comprehensive European Union 2030 strategy, to implement the sustainable development objectives and to improve their integration into the policies and governance mechanisms of the European Union; a strategy based on education, specialisation of professionals and the creation of basic infrastructures. Such a large-scale European policy for sustainable development must be based on an analysis of political deficits and an assessment of the distance to the objectives. It should define clear and distinct objectives, indicators and actions needed to improve political coordination and cohesion policy for sustainable development at European level. To this end, we call on the Commission to carry out an in-depth analysis of the inequality and inadequacy of existing policies in order to identify critical areas in terms of synergies and inconsistencies. Commissioner, we would basically like to know what your plans are to be implemented by 2030, in terms of policies and legislation, statistics and analytical data collection, governance and best practices, with a view to implementing an integrated strategy for the success of agenda 2030 or possible before the end of 2019. The fact that many Member States and partner States beyond the European Union have made considerable efforts to design mechanisms and strategies for the successful implementation of the sustainable development objectives and its integration into their policies and governance is a very, very positive step. However, we need to make further improvements at European Union level and it is also very important to encourage and support third countries to follow similar practices. I would like to conclude my speech by saying that the European Union must be a world leader in the implementation of agenda 2030 and sustainable development objectives in cooperation with its Member States. Our goal must always be constant: the conquest of sustainable development and the wider prosperity of all without discrimination, without queues without being left behind.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, first of all, let me thank the co-rapporteur, Mrs Theocharous and the shadow rapporteurs of the Committees on Development and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, for the ease and understanding they have made it possible for us to reach agreement on an issue which challenges all of us, such as the Sustainable Development Goals. Yesterday we discussed climate change and climate action is one of the objectives to be reviewed this summer at the high-level political forum organized by the United Nations.  The new generations of Europeans are demanding concrete action from us, and our responsibility is to respond to them and we must be clear. We have to explain what we've done so far. We must explain the European success of COP 21, the first international treaty to become environmentally neutral. We must explain that during this mandate, under the Juncker Commission — and with Commissioner Arias Cañete at the helm, both of the European People's Party, both of my political group - and with the ambition of this house, we have made more progress than ever in the fight against climate change. We have approved the circular economy package. We have reviewed the energy package and the renewable energy update. We have revised the Common Electricity Regulation, including for the first time energy poverty in that Regulation. We have renewed the European emissions market. We have approved the Regulation on National Limits. The Commission has just sent us new implementing acts and delegated acts on ecodesign, of which we have also produced a report. We've presented a clean air package. We have approved a single-use plastics directive. In short, we have laid the seed of the Union's economic transformation. We have sown the European industrial revolution of the 21st century.  And we can't fool people. Nature cannot change it from night to day, even if this is difficult to assume in the age of immediacy. Climate change is not mitigated by hanging the photo of a demonstration on Instagram, although we would like it to be so. We must act by being aware of what we can assume and periodically review our progress in research and development, to update our goals and become more and more ambitious. Otherwise, if our industry is relocated, we will not be sustainable in any way, environmentally, socially, or economically. That is why we must see the sustainable development goals as an opportunity. We must be ambitious; yes, but with his feet on the ground. We must seize the opportunity presented to us to renew jobs, to end inequalities within the Union, to establish fair wages that allow workers to maintain a dignified life and progress, as Leo XIII said.  We must use sustainable development goals to reinvent ourselves, not to create more structures. We're wrong if we think that by putting a SDO policeman in every general direction or creating a team, we'll be able to transform it. This is not more structures, but a change of mindset; to improve wealth redistribution instruments; to deepen and strengthen the social market economy that we have integrated into the Union, creating jobs that coerfie and with companies and industries that are based in Europe, not relocated; to create high-value-added jobs and transform our economy so as not to be anchored in the past. To paraphrase Jules Verne, "the land does not need new continents, it needs new women and men".

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes Parliament’s annual strategic report on the implementation and delivery of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This comprehensive and detailed report strongly encourages the EU to lead the implementation of the 2030 agenda and ensure that SDGs guide EU action for the years to come. The report is timely. The European Parliament elections are around the corner. The preparation of the EU’s strategic agenda for 2019-2024 and the institutional priority setting for the next EU policy cycle are on the horizon. The EU has fully committed itself to delivering on the SDGs and it is time to decide how we implement these global goals during the next EU policy cycle so that we can live up to our commitments.  The Commission published the Reflection Paper Towards a Sustainable Europe by 2030 to inspire this debate. We put on the table three indicative scenarios to lead the discussion on how the implementation of the SDGs in Europe could best be achieved and what the most effective division of roles would be between the EU level and the Member States when moving forward. Let me underline that these three scenarios all rely on a shared premise in the Commission that we need enhanced commitment in Europe if we are to secure a sustainable future and achieve the SDGs by 2030 and beyond.  We are in the midst of the fourth industrial revolution. The question is whether we are a victim of change or whether we will embrace and guide it. It starts by diagnosing the situation and facing up to the reality, and undeniability of the facts. I want to be very clear. These facts should not instil in us worry and fear, but inspire us to act with expedience and determination. The core sustainability challenge for Europe, as well as for other most developed parts of the world, is to find the way to increase our prosperity and to improve our wellbeing without destroying our natural habitat and exceeding the boundaries of our planet. We only have one planet. In order to address this challenge, we must move quickly from a linear to a circular economy. We have to put our food system onto a fully sustainable path and we have to green our energy, mobility and built environment. To do this, we also have to gear all our key enabling policies and tools towards the SDGs. These include education, science, research, innovation, digitisation. They also include finance, taxation, pricing and responsible business conduct, new business models. And our trade policy as well, obviously. Any transition must be socially fair and leave no one behind. There is no sustainability without social sustainability and being who we are in Europe all our actions need to fully respect the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights, as well as inclusiveness, facts, evidence.  Let us now move forward with confidence and optimism, for Europe is the best place in the world to lead the way to sustainability transition. We have it all. We have the skills, we have the brains, we have the people, we are the best connected continent and sustainability is deeply rooted in the European project. In the months ahead, we need to reach an agreement on what and how should be done specifically at the EU level in the next EU policy cycle.  The European Parliament’s report clearly favours the first scenario presented in the Commission’s Reflection Paper which proposes an overarching SDG strategy to guide all actions of the EU and its Member States. The Member States too will have to make up their mind. This will help the next Commission plotting a clear course for the development of a comprehensive EU SDG implementation strategy, a strategy that the European Council has called for. I said earlier this week in the informal General Affairs Council that, in both the way we should organise the Commission and our work, the SDGs could be a perfect framework for how we distribute the work and how we make sure that we take the right steps towards a sustainable future for Europe.  The collective contribution conclusion of the SDG high-level multitask platform, ranging from birdlife to business Europe, has made very clear that our people are expecting ambitious action from the EU and its Member States. I want to end by saying, let’s not turn this into a left–right issue. This is an issue that is important to the full political spectrum in this House, and that’s how I’ve always felt the support of this House for the SDGs and this is the way forward. I strongly believe in that.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – I would like to use this minute only for one point and this concerns health. There can be no sustainable development without greater attention to health, and both rapporteurs, one of whom is a doctor, have talked about integrity. Health is not just an aspect or sector, it is a dimension that concerns many partial objectives of our sustainable development strategy. Health trends are worrying, so sectoral strategies to achieve the objectives need to be integrated into such an integral strategy in which health will be a key element. We cannot be a leading force in the world with more cancer, with more diabetes, with several other diseases, the statistics of which we know. So, I want ambition towards a stronger health for the whole of Europe.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a great contradiction between this House - where there are so few of us - and the squares throughout Europe, where tomorrow thousands of young people will go down to strike, to protest, to draw our attention to the climate, to climate change that threatens our future and to inequalities that continue to have a devastating effect on the cohesion and well-being of European society. They understood that the battle for environmental justice is being fought together with the battle for social justice. This House and politics must live up to the demands of Greta Thunberg and those young people.  What is needed to implement the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals are three things, which I still do not see in here: courage, political will and adequate resources. A great Green New Deal of investment would be needed to accompany the ecological transition that is essential for our economy. It is not just a question of saving the planet, but also of creating quality and quantity of jobs, because the two must be together.  Since we were in New York for the adoption of the Sustainable Development Agenda, we have been calling – and we are also calling in today's report – for a European strategy for implementing the Sustainable Development Goals to finally be put in place, with a coordination mechanism between the Member States and with proper monitoring of the achievement of these objectives. With the reflection paper, the Commission has missed the opportunity to take a step forward, pointing in this direction and merely presenting three scenarios, as if they were the same as the other. If we really want to keep our commitments we have no more time, we must finally have this strategy. The EU should guide the implementation of these objectives at global level and demonstrate consistency in its internal and external policies, starting with the budget, the multiannual financial framework and also within the economic semester.  We have an enormous responsibility towards the young people who have been in the squares tomorrow and in recent months. We can't be out of our way.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the strategy for achieving the SDGs, we must adopt a general principle: it must be a development in order to improve the quality of life of society for the present and future generations, and not to maximise profit for the individual at all costs. However, a mandatory clause should be added that no one will be left out. There must therefore be harmony and order in social, economic and environmental policies with the maintenance of economic efficiency. The priority is to protect fundamental values, i.e. man and respect for nature.  Global sustainable development therefore needs to: develop and consolidate democracy and human rights, promote good governance, humanitarian aid, human capital development, entrepreneurship and the private sector, promote sustainable agriculture, rural development and environmental protection, strengthen health care, sustainable management of natural resources and waste, reduce unemployment and society poverty. We must constantly remember that the environment and the environment of civilised people operate on the principle of connected vessels, so that the vessels on both sides must be filled with values.

name: Mirja VEHKAPERÄ
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Sustainable Development Goals were agreed four years ago. A lot of work has been done on them, but the work is still ongoing. Only a handful of EU countries reach the target of 0.7% of development funding. EU countries are poorly placed in the sustainability of consumption and production methods. More than 22% of EU citizens live in poverty or at risk of social exclusion, and inequality has increased. In particular, the EU must understand the universality of the SDC. Achieving them requires coherence between all policy areas. For example, the transition to climate neutrality, resource efficiency and the circular economy will play a key role in strengthening the EU's growth and competitiveness. The Commission is lagging behind in adopting a comprehensive strategy. The reflection paper proposing the strategy is therefore very welcome. Ambition and leadership are needed to draw up a strategy. The next EU financial framework is currently being negotiated, and a new Commission and Parliament will soon be elected. We therefore have a valuable opportunity to anchor the SDGs as a key part of EUROPEAN policy. I hope that at the May Sibiu Summit in Romania, the EU will show leadership and bring sustainable development into a strong part of the debate on the future of Europe.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for this strategic INI report which serves as an input from the Parliament ahead of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) summit of September 2019, and also as a reaction to the recent Commission reflection paper. But Parliament stresses that more efforts are required from the Member States and the Commission. We need finally an all—encompassing, transformative EU 2030 strategy that integrates SDGs into all EU policies and applies a multi—level approach in governance in line with the recent Think 2030 work. It is not enough to use our existing policies, tools or indicators. We need a real paradigm shift, mainstreaming, and concrete tangible actions, targets and deadlines, including a robust sustainability proofing, consistent indicators and an effective monitoring framework. All EU infrastructure decisions, all EU revenues and expenditures must be aligned with the SDGs and the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) should reflect this to the fullest. In order to safeguard these principles, the EU still has a long way to go.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, our society, our economy, and our consumption and production patterns must fundamentally change in order to keep the earth livable. It is good that global agreements have been made on this in the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. However, it must not be just fine words. We really need to act. Right away. There is no other option. There is no planet B. That climate policy is so inadequate that thousands of young people are forced to leave the school benches for the streets, which should lead to deep, deep shame, but above all to meaningful action. I hear the Commissioner talk about a good and comprehensive plan. But the fact that agricultural, fisheries and trade policies can continue at the same time as climate, biodiversity, food security, the welfare of millions of people and billions of animals undermines all the fine words that are said here in this House. Tolstoy once said, "Everyone thinks about changing the world, but hardly anyone thinks about changing themselves." And he was right. In order to achieve the sustainable development goals, we must also look at ourselves, and we must produce less meat and dairy, but also consume less. In order to achieve the sustainable development goals, the destructive EU policy needs to change radically. Right away. That is also why I believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, when it comes to sustainability in this House, we are always talking about the environmental aspects. However, I would like to talk to you about the sustainability of society and culture. Because it is undeniably under pressure. From the outside because of the migration of large groups of people from mainly Muslim countries who have nothing to do with our culture, who do not wish to adapt, who find their own culture superior and turn themselves against our culture. But also from the inside. Also from the inside. Mr President, the left-wing parties that want to break down as much culture and identity as possible from society. And culture and identity, these are the roots of our society. If you poison those roots, if you damage those roots, the organism will die. So next time we talk about sustainability, we'd like to talk about sustainability of society and sustainability of culture. The survival of our Western society. The survival of our Western society – that is also sustainability – is based on the Judeo-Christian and humanist traditions, as we know them and as we wish to preserve them.

name: Bogusław SONIK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The report on the implementation of the SDGs is the European Parliament's contribution to the first ever Report to the UN on monitoring and reviewing progress towards the SDGs by the European Union and its Member States in addition to voluntary national reviews.  These objectives can only be achieved through a comprehensive European Union strategy and their integration into the EU's internal and external policies and management mechanisms in line with the number one scenario presented by the European Commission in its reflection paper of January this year. That is why it is so important for the Commission to analyse the gaps in existing policies, to implement them, to identify the most important areas where there are inconsistencies, and to develop a framework for monitoring and reviewing individual objectives from the perspective of the European Union and the Member States.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, we are on the eve of another march against climate change, including in my own home country, Malta. Youths and students are getting mobilised, but this is not only about the younger generation, this is not just about the future, this is about all of us, it is about now. A UN report stated that temperatures are set to rise by at least 1.5° by 2030 if the world does not take drastic measures. An increase of 1.5° in temperature can result in an increase in the sea level of 3.45 m. Just ask yourselves what it means for coastal areas, for people and islands like mine that live next to the sea, for low—lying countries. This is the challenge that we are facing today and we are at a time where we are speaking about industry 4.0, the fourth industrial revolution. We are told it is about digitisation and it is about automation. I tend to differ. It has to also be about ecological economies and about sustainable development and this is the moment for an economic paradigm shift. Being sustainable in everything we do does not jam our economies, it will give our economies a chance to thrive and grow. What will jam our economies is the traditional model of doing things where sustainable development is not a priority. Change requires ambition, ambition requires aspiration, an aspiration that we want to do better, to move to the next level in everything we do, to ensure a future for our children and our economies.  This positive transformation has to start from our countries but needs to find momentum at an EU level. It is about ensuring health, eradicating poverty, providing quality jobs and guaranteeing food security. The Sustainable Development Goals address precisely this. It is about ensuring a climate—proof, environment—proof, social—proof and economic—proof future. The discussions have started and the momentum is there. We need to make sure that we act in a decisive way that helps us future proof our societies.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Mr President, I thank the Commissioner for his fine words. As many times as he's spoken here, those are really nice words. But words, and certainly fine words, only really gain value if they act accordingly. Unfortunately, I have questioned these sustainable development goals. I wanted to unpack two to make it clear: number 14 and number 15. Living underwater and living on land. In other words, natural biodiversity. That's what it's all about. We have a European biodiversity strategy. And we had them long before we had sustainable development goals. This strategy, which we consider so terribly important, is that the European Commission had also given it the name 'Our life insurance, our natural capital'. Billions of people around the world, and certainly in Europe, depend on that natural capital, on nature. We have also known for years that we are not going to achieve the goals of our own self-formulated biodiversity strategy. It ends this year. In 2015, we received the "State-of-Nature" report from the European Environment Agency which showed that all indicators are red. Studies have been published on the mass disappearance of insects. What has the Commission done, but what have the Member States done? Nothing at all. In fact, we in this House had to walk out of the fire and speak tongues on the blisters in order to prevent further weakening of nature legislation. So, Madam President, a very simple question to the European Commission: what is the Commission going to do, to get much closer to achieving the goals of our own biodiversity...? (The speaker is interrupted by the President.)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, the Commission’s reflection paper shows that the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) must guide all the EU’s policy work as a matter of urgency. We need an overarching EU sustainability strategy and, likewise, concrete and time-bound deliverables for 2030. The SDGs also require a new way of policy making, which must be cross-sectoral and not embedded in silence. All the policies and all the institutions of the EU must be geared towards achieving the SDGs. In the European Parliament, we also need strong mechanisms which involve all policy sectors, from agriculture to industry, from transport to employment, and everything in between. The European Parliament, with this report, shows that it wants to achieve this new way of making policy and Parliament is going to send a delegation to the high-level political forum and it is crucial that the European Parliament will be present this year, as the EU itself will report on its progress.  We need to look at global supply chains and I thank you very much, Vice-President Timmermans, for mentioning responsible business conduct, it’s a key to achieving our goals.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I would like to ask Mrs Hautala what she does personally for the environment. So what she's really sacrificing. So I'm not talking about subsidised electric cars or LED lights. No, what you're really sacrificing. Do you shower cold every day, for example? You're not taking the plane anymore? Do you have all the electrical appliances anyway? Don't have pets? Don't you eat meat? What are you really sacrificing what really hurts, what really hurts?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: blue-card answer. – This is a wonderful question. I can tell you, young man, that I was a co-founder of a vegetarian restaurant in 1974 when I was just a kid, and I have followed that path all my life.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Madam President, the first meeting of heads of state will be held in September to assess the progress of the 2030 Agenda and it will be time to fill the gaps in the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. Political coherence for development must be imposed at all levels and at all levels, but the elephant in the room is called trade policy.  We must provide the Sustainable Development Goals with a cross-cutting gender perspective, and they must also be the guiding principles of our agricultural, fisheries and consumption policies, and of course we must align the multiannual financial framework with the objectives of the Agenda.  The progress being made is insufficient—that is clear—and will continue to be so as long as some key questions remain taboo, because, despite investing millions in sustainable development, we never hear of some fundamental issues. When we discuss the objective of 'zero hunger', we must dare to talk about food sovereignty and restrict food stock speculation; when we talk about the "end of poverty," let's talk about ending extreme wealth; when it comes to 'health and well-being', let us ask ourselves about the privatization of health and patents; and, instead of yielding dogmatic pleitism to the goal of economic growth, let's look for balance on a planet that is finite.  Mr Timmermans, saving the oppressed has always been romantic, but from here, I propose that we begin by identifying the forces that oppress them and putting them to a stop.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the 2030 Agenda is based on the Union’s core values of democracy, participation, good governance, social justice, solidarity, sustainability and respect for the rule of law and human rights within the EU, its Member States, and around the globe.  The 2030 agenda is vital to achieving greater wellbeing for all and a fair world, leaving no one behind. The four essential pillars of sustainable development – social, environmental, economic and governance – must be put into practice. The fair transition to a sustainable low-carbon economy that is inclusive for all is an essential part of this. I strongly welcome this report’s call on the Commission to draw up an ambitious strategy for the implementation of the 2030 agenda and I think it’s important to emphasise the importance of sustainable food production.  Finally, I want to say that every Member State should commit to giving 0.7% to development aid as we’ve asked. I’m delighted that my Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, has indicated that Ireland is going to do so.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today's analysis shows us that the Sustainable Development Goals must be and remain the main aim of the European Union. We need to do a thorough analysis of the policies we have had. We have or do not have the results expected by citizens related to cohesion. We need to see what the results of the policies are, and we need to see whether, indeed, the financial effort and the work that we have done, the national parliaments and national governments have led to the eradication of poverty, have led to a better situation of citizens' incomes. No one should be left behind, it said here. Then we must understand that, in management, the analysis requires us to make corrections to our policies and, therefore, I think that we must take into account, Commissioner, in the policies that we will do in the future, 2030 is not very far away, from the concrete situations on the ground, from the more remote areas, from poorer areas and, obviously, to take into account subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we welcome the report on the implementation of the sustainable development objectives and it is important that there is the annual report so that we can monitor progress and, above all, see whether the objectives that have been set can actually be set. And I think that the objectives, as mentioned, are important, based mainly on democracy, solidarity, the protection of human rights. And the key element, of course, for sustainable development first of all is to create jobs. Because it is possible to have growth without jobs. We want growth with jobs. Above all, this development must be carried out in such a way as to exploit resources, to use resources for the peoples themselves, especially for the peoples of the developing world, in order to tackle poverty and achieve social justice. In this way, migration flows from the developing world to Europe will also be reduced and democracy can be established in both the European Union and the developing world.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, sustainability and the transition to a climate-neutral, circular and socially inclusive economy are crucial to ensuring the long-term growth and competitiveness of the European Union. The 2030 Agenda has the potential to determine this, setting ambitious, global, indivisible and interconnected universal goals. However, at present, the Commission has not yet defined a comprehensive strategy for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda that includes the European Union's internal and external strategic sectors, with detailed deadlines until 2030, nor has it included the Sustainable Development Goals as a general framework in the revised 2017 guidelines. More effort is needed on the part of the Member States and the Commission. We need a general strategy across all policies and a multi-level approach to governance. The instruments currently available are not enough: we need a paradigm shift, sustainability verification and an effective monitoring framework. The revenue from the next multiannual financial framework will need to be more oriented towards the Sustainable Development Goals. The way to go is not easy, but we must do it for the new generations.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, just to react to a few things that were said. I think we have a huge opportunity to do exactly what Mr Caputo has just said, to organise this paradigm change. I sensed also, when I spoke to the ministers in the General Affairs Council earlier this week, that in the Member States things are shifting as well in this direction. So, I think after the European election this Parliament with the new Commission could have a huge opportunity to frame the activities of the next five years using the Strategic Development Goals (SDGs). I think we have this opportunity now and I think there is growing consensus also in Member States to do that. That would be my first remark.  My second remark is this: those who, in general terms, deny climate change – you even have people who deny all the scientific evidence – those who want to say that if you want to have a sustainable society we all will have to live in caves munching on grass, should understand that this project fear is not going to fly, because there is a way, if we are consistent and if we move quickly, to have high levels of well-being and still not use the planet as though we have two more planets waiting for us. There is a way to do that. But the issue is, the longer you wait, the more difficult it’s going to be and I believe the only way we can get our societies to embrace the idea is to put social sustainability front and centre. There, I fully agree with Mr Marias when he says you have to make sure you can convince the people there is a sustainable future for them in this, with a decent job, with decent salaries, with decent social protection. If they have the feeling that they’re going to be the ones living in caves munching on grass, they will stop. They will not give the political support we need to go in that direction. So I think we need to put this front and centre. To Mr Gerbrandy, I would say, well, Sir, if you think that’s the fact, what this Commission has done is because of your tenacity I grant you that with pleasure. But I have to say the way Ms Ska Keller recently said somewhere that better regulation has led to lowering of standards, I think better regulation has given us the possibility to have the European’s view, for instance on the nature directives. We could not have protected the nature directives if we did not have this public consultation, which said very clearly that the vast, vast majority of Europeans want the nature directives to protect nature. So, in that sense, better regulation helped and it helped us to move with lightning speed on the plastic strategy, which is unique in the world and Mr Gerbrandy knows this very well. It also helped us move with lightning speed on the first steps of the circular economy, which is something also Commissioner Jyrki Katainen has done a lot of work on and which is very good for our collective future. So, you know, all the fears we had at the beginning that this would lead to lower ambitions and a lowering of standards, this did not happen. This is not what this Commission did. I think we really moved forward.  Finally, one remark on cultural sustainability. Isn’t it ironic, isn’t it ironic that the political movements who do everything to cut cultural subsidies and say this is for the elite, are the same movements who are pleading for us to safeguard our culture and foster our culture. For me, culture is not an exclusive thing. For me, culture is not a weapon to exclude other people. For me, culture is the way to develop pride in who we are and curiosity in who we are not, and curiosity is the way forward for our development. Without curiosity, without critical thinking, we will not be able to go forward and those who want to make us prisoner of a culture in fear of other cultures will kill curiosity, will kill creativity and will not help us move forward.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I too would like to thank Commissioner Timmermans for his inspiring first speech and for the answers, as well as Mr Gambús and the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution. I would particularly agree with Mr Peterle that health is a key aspect of development. There can be no development without health infrastructure and there can be no health infrastructure without training doctors, midwies, nurses, technicians and teachers. Education, therefore, is the strongest driver for growth. I think that much of what has been said by colleagues is embedded in the perspectives of this report. We will try to achieve the sustainable development goals without withdrawals and regressions. The basic condition, of course, is to dispose of 0.7 of the gross national product of the Member States for this purpose.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I thank you again for the words you heard in this morning's debate. I hope that the debate we have had here and the vote we will have this noon will help us to encourage and renew efforts to achieve a broadcast-neutral society as soon as possible. But for Europe to be broadcast neutral, if we do not get other key players to accompany us, it will be of little use. The Union is prepared to lead — and indeed leads — the process of achieving the Objectives set out in the 2030 Agenda, but as in the fable of the turtle and the hare 'not because we are the fastest we will reach the goal first'. Let us keep the path, do not fall asleep and achieve the objectives we have set ourselves. That is why, as Commissioner Arias Cañete said yesterday, Parliament and the Commission emerging from the next elections will be key to this — you said this today, Mr Timmermans. They will be responsible for the 2021-2027 financial framework. They will be responsible for such important revisions as the Water Framework Directive linked to Agenda 2030 Objective 6. But it is not just the work of the Commission, nor just the work of the European Parliament. We must ensure multi-level collaboration and governance because the skills we have in Europe are limited. We must organize dialogues and have the participation of the local, regional, state and European levels to, together with the common foreign policy, lead the achievement of these Objectives. We must preserve the Union, ensure its diversity, listen to all voices, however small, so that we all felt part of this Union.  The Sustainable Development Goals are the key to broadening the sense of belonging to this european peace project and to leave behind the usual commentary on "what do you do in Europe" to move on to 'what we have done in Europe'. And what we do, Mr Vice-President, you are absolutely right, is not a matter of right or left, it is a matter of being European and of wanting to lead the world and in that we must be one. We're responsible for that.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, March 14, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – It is regrettable that there are still significant differences in achieving the 10th Sustainable Development Goal in terms of reducing income inequalities and inequalities based on age, gender, disability, ethnicity, origin, religion and economic situation. I am sure that inclusive and equitable education, science, technology and innovation can increase equal opportunities and reduce social exclusion at the same time, and therefore this should play a much greater role in the future. Unfortunately, in many developing countries, progress towards the SDGs cannot be properly measured, but unfortunately it is still clear that the risk of poverty among children is too high. Early investment in children's education is a major pay-off for both children and society as a whole, so it is crucial to breaking the vicious circle of disadvantage in the early years.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Christofer Fjellner's report, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the implementation of Regulation (EU) 978/2012 on the System of Generalized Preferences (GSP) (2018/2107 (INI)) (A8-0090/2019).

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, free trade is one of the best ways to lift countries out of poverty: history proves that with all accuracy. Let’s take the Netherlands, for example, which developed when its citizens became freer to trade in the 17th century; and my own country, Sweden, started 100 years of growth in the 1870s when we opened up for trade. And growth miracles are not just a thing of the past: in Korea and, right now, China, they would not have happened if those countries had integrated into the world economy, and that is actually what is the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP) is all about. I would call it the crown jewel of European trade policy because it tries to link poor countries into the world economy and lift them out of poverty. Many countries in the world have GSP programmes, but I believe that we in the European Union should be extra proud of our programme. It’s a very generous programme, in its terms, giving value and meaningful tariff cuts to the beneficiaries. It’s also extra generous to the poorest countries of the world that get duty-free, quota-free access to the European markets for everything but arms. The best part of GSP, though, is the GSP+, which grants additional preferences to those countries that strive a little more and try to behave better by implementing, ratifying and making a reality of 27 international conventions on everything from governance to environment and labour rights. It is a tool to extra-incentivise countries, to make sure that they grow and develop in a way that is sustainable and from which all their citizens can benefit. It’s a way to make sure that good governance is respected. We are now reaching the mid term of this programme and we are starting to see what can and should be improved, and this report reflects that. Firstly, it needs to become easier for beneficiary countries to source inputs from other countries, and that will require changing rules of origin to get away from the ‘spaghetti bowl’ effect. This programme is about making it easier for countries to integrate into global value chains, not more difficult – as can sometimes be the effect of the current rules of origin. Secondly, we should continually improve monitoring on the ground, and here everybody can help – civil society, the International Labour Organisation, relevant UN bodies, the Commission, Member States, embassies and others. Thirdly, we should consider introducing services into the GSP, so that countries can diversify into those areas as well. There is a precedent for this with the Least-Developed Countries (LDC) Services Waiver. This report represents the priorities for the programme – indicating how it should be even more development orientated – but there are voices which threaten that. The first such voices, I would say, are those seeking to place too many requirements on beneficiary countries. If we place too many requirements – on, for example, labour rights or environmental protection – on these countries they could risk facing the entire EU tariff wall, and that would harm the poorest. These countries are not Norway: if they were Norway they wouldn’t need this tool. After all, it’s better to be less poor and oppressed than being even poorer and more oppressed. The second type of voice is a classic example of protectionism: of the fact that we are afraid of imports from poorer countries. And, sadly, I think the Commission’s decision to impose safeguard duties on rice from Cambodia and Myanmar is a step in that direction. This report does not reflect any of those fears and I sincerely hope that the next Parliament will deal with the next GSP programme without listening to the voices who threaten trade for development.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank the European Parliament, the Committee on International Trade (INTA), the rapporteur, Mr Christofer Fjellner, and all the shadow rapporteurs for the attention, work and time that you have invested into this report on the implementation of the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP) Regulation. It is a welcome initiative, as it comes at a moment when we are assessing the impact and effectiveness of the current GSP Regulation and what possible improvements we can bring to a successor GSP scheme.  The EU has had the GSP scheme since 1971. The primary objective, as set out in the WTO Enabling Clause, has always been to assist vulnerable developing countries in their efforts to reduce poverty and integrate into the world economy. The European Union’s GSP has undergone several transformations over the decades. A major reform of the GSP took place in 2012, with three main objectives: first, to contribute to poverty eradication by expanding exports from the countries most in need. This was done by substantially reducing the number of beneficiaries and focusing GSP preferences on the most vulnerable economies. Secondly, to promote sustainable development and good governance. We increased the attractiveness of GSP+ and enhanced the GSP+ monitoring of effective implementation of core international conventions related to human rights, labour rights, protection of the environment and good governance. Thirdly, to better protect the EU’s financial and economic interests. In this respect, the safeguard mechanism was overhauled to make it more accessible to EU industry. We are now five years into the implementation of the GSP Regulation and I am pleased to note that overall, the European Parliament and the Commission share the assessment that the GSP Regulation is successful in meeting its objectives. Exports from the more vulnerable economies have expanded substantially, which can contribute to poverty eradication. GSP, and in particular GSP+, is also contributing positively to furthering human and labour rights in beneficiary countries. We agree with your view that trade policy, including GSP, must also be part of EU efforts to fight for values enshrined in the EU treaties, such as democracy, rule of law and human rights. Trade policy does not and cannot do this on its own or in isolation. We take great care to ensure coherence between all EU external policies. For example, we ensure that GSP+ dialogues and bilateral human rights dialogues with beneficiary countries reinforce each other, thus increasing the EU’s leverage to push for progress. As the Commission’s biannual reports on GSP+ implementation attest, we are seeing progress in all beneficiary countries. However, many problematic issues remain and we will continue to engage closely and firmly with beneficiary countries.  I would like to touch on an issue that is very important to us, namely, transparency in trade policy. In the implementation of the GSP Regulation, we make considerable efforts to ensure a transparent and inclusive process. We consult civil society in the European Union and in beneficiary countries on a very regular basis and we are always open to their input, which we greatly value. We do not always share their views on what course of action should be taken at a specific point in time, but this should not be taken to mean that we do not listen to civil society. Let me be very clear: the Commission will not hesitate to take its responsibilities when it comes to warranted cases of serious and systematic violation of fundamental rights. Our actions in relation to Cambodia and Myanmar clearly demonstrate this. In this respect, I agree with you that withdrawing GSP must be a last-resort measure.  We must now start work on the new GSP scheme that will take effect when the current one expires on 31 December 2023. As we have seen in the mid—term evaluation of the GSP Regulation, it is working well overall and this should be the starting point. Your report and resolution contains several proposals that we will examine carefully. The next immediate step in this process is to launch an impact assessment to help guide our work on a new GSP Regulation. This will include a wide-ranging public consultation. We count on working closely with you on this important endeavour.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for human rights and democracy cannot be taken for granted, but must be strengthened by every means available. The European Union is the main promoter of human rights in the world and its trade policies must also ensure that they are asserted. Through GSP+, the EU allows vulnerable countries to export to Europe duty-free. In return, it requires compliance with 27 international conventions on human rights, work and the environment. I believe that this trade scheme is an important lever for supporting democracy and improving the human rights situation in the beneficiary countries. In some cases, however, despite serious violations, the European Union has not suspended preferential treatment. It is therefore necessary to step up the consultation process on the regular monitoring of the European Union of beneficiary states and to clearly define the red lines of the scheme which, if exceeded, involve the suspension of the GSP.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, the European Union's trade policy, through the System of Generalized Preferences, promotes sustainable development and respect for human rights in countries with the most vulnerable economies in the world.  As Mr Fjellner's report reflects, the GSP has brought economic benefits to the beneficiary countries by increasing their exports, and also to the European Union. In general, the GSP has been shown to play an important role in promoting international labour rights, human rights, good governance and environmental protection standards in beneficiary countries.  But we must not forget that, in some cases, this increase in exports has generated undesing effects on fundamental rights and social development. In this regard, I would like to point out that trade preferences must be accompanied by the implementation of international conventions and reforms, in order to prevent GSP programmes from increasing levels of environmental and social dumping.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, and I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work. I deeply defend the system of widespread preferences because it is a fundamental trade policy tool for promoting sustainable development in less advanced countries.  Abolishing tariffs in these countries in exchange for promoting the protection of human, labour and environmental rights, as well as good governance, has undoubtedly encouraged better employment and enabled us to combat the scourge of child exploitation and corruption and help combat poverty. But progress is still not enough and unfortunately we are seeing serious setbacks in some countries. Reform is therefore essential and I welcome the re-action that it will be receptive to the proposals that are incorporated in this report. Because it is necessary to strengthen the effectiveness of the system, control its implementation and ensure that concessions are withdrawn as the last solution in case of serious violations of the commitments made.  It is also necessary to establish due diligence and transparency obligations for our companies because we cannot allow it to occur in other less advanced countries – taking advantage of the lower labour and environmental protections – and then these products are sold in our countries at a zero tariff. And I also think it is very important to encourage companies that (inaudible word) produce in a sustainable way. Let's improve regulation and delve into a system that has worked but needs to improve its implementation.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, our GSP system is a key example of how we use our economic power to leverage our weight and to bring about positive change for people in third countries, and the report that we’re adopting today illustrates how GSP beneficiaries have, over the course of six years, substantially increased their exports to the EU. But this kind of preferential access should not be taken for granted. It is attached to clear conditions, for example when it comes to improving democracy, human rights and the rule of law, and following the increasingly repressive behaviour of Cambodian leader Hun Sen, Commissioner Malmström initiated a procedure to temporarily withdraw Cambodia’s trade preferences, under the Everything but Arms scheme, and this is a very welcome move, that should be echoed by all Member States’ Commissioners, as well as the High Representative in all their dealings with Cambodia. And at the same time we cannot wait another second to initiate a similar procedure for Myanmar. The ongoing killings, systematic human rights violations and the imprisonment of journalists, do not warrant the trade preferences that Myanmar currently does enjoy.  So, I believe it is very important that we use GSP in a good, but also principled, way and thereby maximise our global impact.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP) instrument has a great potential to ensure that trade and sustainable development are intrinsically linked. But the effectiveness of the GSP system has been put into question. It does not necessarily improve social and environmental conditions, it does not necessarily promote human rights. I believe that a black and white approach of withdrawing tariff preferences from a whole country also has not proved effective. We have examples such as Myanmar and Cambodia and I think the options have to be increased. I believe that instead of a whole economy, the EU should be able to target certain economic sectors with GSP instruments. Moreover, it should be able to use targeted sanctions against companies that breach human rights or other obligations. So, we should be able to blacklist companies or exporters that are found guilty of abusing human rights. I’d like to ask the Commissioner: are you ready to establish a complaint mechanism for victims of European Union enterprises in the context of the GSP+?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Fjellner, it is not a question of trade, it is about fair and ethical trade. And I think that your report on the GSP paints a too positive picture. Five years ago, in the last major reform of the GSP system, despite strong criticism from my group and from civil society, all the countries that had reached a middle income, according to the World Bank, were removed from the preference list. Today, only eight countries benefit from the GSP+. The flagship of our preferential system is therefore hardly used. That's not how we make the world a better place. We must replace the criterion of 'poverty' with the criterion of 'respect for human rights' for the granting of trade preferences. The Commission must show that it also withdraws tariff concessions when human rights are violated. So, commissioner, take action now, also in the cases of Cambodia and Myanmar. Start the procedure to the Philippines. The year 2022 is the expiry date of the current GSP Regulation. In other words, after the European elections, the reform is at the top of the list of the most important tasks in the field of trade for the new Parliament and the new Commission.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to use trade to help developing countries, but we must also protect European sensitivities and prevent a new case such as that of Asian rice from occurring.  It is not acceptable to use poor countries as huge agricultural plantations. We need to differentiate and create local work, developing services and industry. We also need social clauses, because we can no longer allow European multinationals to relocate outside Europe to produce where workers are exploited for a few euros a day.  For this reason, I support the idea of safeguard measures not only for agricultural or industrial products, but also for respect for social and environmental rights. However, we must ensure that safeguards are activated immediately. In the case of rice, it took five years. In future, we will have to be much, but much, faster, or europeans will also suffer.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been giving tariff preferences to developing countries for 40 years since the Lomé conference, supposedly to facilitate development by integrating the poorest countries into world trade. Forty years later, the failure is obvious. All development indicators show stagnation or even regression on all fronts. This system serves as a moral guarantor for slavers in developing countries. In a meeting with the Bangladeshi Embassy, with astonishing relativism, we were told very seriously - after yet another fire in a chemical plant that resulted in dozens of deaths - that there were fires all over the world, including in the most developed countries. Of the 1,000 chemical factories and warehouses in Bangladesh's capital, 850 are illegal and do not meet any standards. The unscrupulous leaders of many countries are playing us and see from this system only the money they can extract from it. This system is therefore costly, inefficient, sometimes disastrous for men, women and children and their rights, and above all economically absurd.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Madam President, the Generalised Scheme of Preferences is one of three schemes that the EU offers to developing countries. It’s entirely sensible to encourage developing countries to integrate into world trade. I myself have stood on a manifesto calling for ‘trade, not aid’, and certainly the benefits that derive from trade are likely to last much longer than those that derive from aid. But – and it is a big but – the EU uses these schemes to advance its own political agenda. This is not just me saying this. The EU itself, the Trade Commissioner and MEP colleagues, have been very clear, indeed transparent, about it. They have even been rather proud of it, as was Ms Schaake earlier, in a very good speech. To give one example, Sri Lanka, never a rich country, suffered badly from the 2004 tsunami. Notwithstanding, the EU shortly afterwards withdrew the GSP+ scheme from Sri Lanka for entirely political reasons. In a word, that action was spiteful. It must not happen again.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the GSP represents a tariff cut for developing countries, aid that is granted in exchange for a commitment to achieving standards relating to human rights and sustainable development, which are then often disregarded. We are well known that there are serious shortcomings in the mechanisms for the environmental management of waste from the production sector – especially textiles – in these countries.  I would also like to highlight the damage and distortion that the European Union market can suffer from the recognition of these benefits. In fact, although there is a safeguard clause, it is slow and cumbersome to activate. I would remind you of rice from Myanmar and Cambodia, where this procedure cost Italy damage and a very long job: 5 years. In addition, the procedures by which the list of States benefiting from these preferences may be subject to variations, with additions or expulsions, are very complex and opaque. If Europe really wants to improve the conditions of its neighbours and distant partners and to support their development, it needs to find coherence. We cannot impose increasingly stringent and penalising rules on our businesses and reward those who do not even comply with the minimum environmental standards and civil rights outside Europe's borders.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the system of generalised preferences, by reducing tariffs, has moved on in order, supposedly, to support the developing world. However, what we saw was that it was primarily exploited by the multinationals, which by outsourcing found cheap labour in the developing world, where no standards are observed, either to protect the health and safety of workers, not for wages, nor, of course, for human rights. And what is practically happening is that there is a social dumping. In fact, cheap products are produced within developing countries, which are imported duty-free into the European Union and the rest, thus creating unfair competition. So, in practice, this whole system, instead of helping the workers themselves, has essentially turned them into even poorer ones in developing countries and all it has done is increase the profits of multinationals at the expense of both workers and small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the comments and input during this debate. We remain firmly committed to trade policy contributing, together with other EU policies, to championing respect for universal and fundamental values. In this respect, GSP is an important trade policy tool, designed for developing countries. By helping to expand exports from beneficiary countries, it has contributed to bringing millions out of poverty. It is also contributing to furthering human rights and sustainable development. The Commission, together with the European External Action Service, will continue to monitor closely, and engage firmly, with beneficiary countries. We will also start examining what improvements can be brought to a new GSP Regulation, including many of your clear proposals and requests, so that it can continue to be a force for good. We look forward to working with the European Parliament on this high—priority EU trade policy file.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I’d like to thank the Commissioner and to thank my colleagues for a good debate. I see two main trends in this debate. First, we have those who say we are not seeing the kind of development we want. I urge them – those who claim that we have stagnation, that we don’t have development of poor countries – actually to read the statistics. The fact of the matter is that we’ve never, ever in the history of mankind, had so few people in absolute poverty And there is no causal link to aid, should anybody look for that. The only causal link we can find is with integration into the world economy and, to some extent, with governance. Both of these are things we are addressing with precisely this tool. The second area, on which we have had long discussions, time and time again, in the committee, is the question of what we do with those that don’t behave. There are people here who give the impression that we don’t do anything, but that’s not true. First of all, Sri Lanka is one example of the fact that that you do actually lose your preference if you don’t behave, and what we now are doing with Myanmar is also a proof of that. However, we have to remember one thing: when countries are kicked out of the system, the system doesn’t deliver anymore. This is, to some extent, a question about what we see and what we don’t see. We see, in the history books, things that happen, but we never see things that do not happen – as the result of dialogue, of pressure or of this tool. I would claim that we’ve improved livelihoods, and the situation in terms of observance of human rights, for millions throughout this world by stopping things from happening, because people want to stay in the system. If we kick people out too quickly we lose that possibility. Therefore, I urge my colleagues, let’s be tough, let’s strengthen monitoring, but let’s not punish those already oppressed by making them poorer and kicking them out before we’ve used every trick in this regulation to pressure those governments that are behaving badly into behaving better.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, March 14, 2019.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on six motions for a resolution on the human rights situation in Kazakhstan (2019/2610 (RSP)).

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: author. – Madam President, it’s very important that the European Parliament now addresses the worsening human rights and democratic standards situation in Kazakhstan. This is a country which has signed an enhanced partnership and cooperation agreement with the European Union and this agreement aims at providing a broad framework for reinforced political dialogue. There is no doubt that the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms and principles of market economy and sustainable development must be at the core of the negotiations. Now we know that there are many victims of politically motivated charges. There are many political prisoners, there is torture in the prisons and we, as the European Union, must react to the worsening of the situation. We must also address the situation of trade union activists – I’m mentioning two names, there are more in our common resolution – Nurbek Kushakbaev and Amin Eleusinov were released on parole in May 2018, but they remain banned from trade union activities. This is not possible, with a country which has an enhanced partnership ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. Yes, we are satisfied that the European Parliament is addressing human rights violations in Kazakhstan. Indeed, we signed a strengthened cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan in 2015 in which respect for the rule of law and human rights are a fundamental part. Nevertheless, as an MEP, I am confronted with testimonies by Kazakh citizens who are being curtailed in their fundamental rights. This is done in many ways, although they are not always visible to the outside world. Harassment, legal harassment, torture, involuntary arrest and preventive confinement. Free life is curtailed to protect the regime of President Nazarbayev. I specifically mention the names of political prisoners: Maks Bokayev, Iskander Yerimbetov or Mukhtar Dzhakishev. They are silenced. We, the European Parliament, are also victims. Activists who wanted to communicate their concerns to an AFET delegation from this House in September last year were skilfully shielded and silenced by Kazakh authorities. I ask the EEAS and the Commission not only to look for – undeniably interesting – business and economic links with Kazakhstan, but above all to insist in the talks on respect for fundamental values that we hold in Europe.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is one of the central lessons of the collapse of real socialist societies 30 years ago that social and political human rights are inextricably linked. To guarantee this, we need to strengthen the rule of law, democracy and freedom. This applies everywhere, because democracy and the participation and participation of people in social development processes must be possible everywhere. It is therefore regrettable that the human rights and civil liberties situation in Kazakhstan has deteriorated in recent years, especially since legislation against extremism has been used to persecute political opponents. Recent expressions of popular dissatisfaction – we have many reports of this – show the willingness and need of citizens for a more democratic participation in their society. That is why the politically motivated cases of persecution must also be brought to an end quickly.

name: Wolf KLINZ
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Kazakhstan became an independent state. With this development, the citizens of the country have hoped that, after many years of authoritarian rule, this country will finally develop into a democratic country – a country in which freedom and fundamental rights are valid, where freedom of expression exists, where the rule of law and the rules of the market economy apply, and where all citizens can live safely and freely and can develop prosperity.  Unfortunately, this hope has not been fulfilled. The EU is Kazakhstan's largest trading partner and, in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement in December 2015, reiterated the importance of respect ingesity and respect for EU-Kazakhstan cooperation. Unfortunately, more than three years after this agreement, we have to say that nothing has improved, on the contrary, and in some cases the situation has become even worse.  Innocent people are imprisoned, tortured, there is no freedom of expression, and political opponents are persecuted. I am therefore pleased that Members of this House have come together across party lines on this motion for a resolution to urge the government to do something.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Author. – Madam President, the visit of an AFET mission to Kazakhstan last September, which I was part of, has laid bare the repressive stupidity of the Nursultan Nazarbayev regime which lives on the cult of delusional personality at the head of a totalitarian and kleptocratic system. In front of our delegation in Almaty, kazakh police arrested activists who wanted to contact us. At the time, we demand the immediate release of these victims and all other citizens arrested and tortured by a regime that restricts the Internet, represses human rights activists and any opponent. Today, in this resolution, we demand that all who, like Mukhtar Dzhakishev, who is about to lose sight of, iskander Yerimbetov, Aset Abishev, and so many others who are listed, including supporters of the Democratic Choice movement of Kazakhstan, or all who take to the streets in the colours of that movement. Next week, Nazarbayev will grant presidential pardons. It is time for the European Union to make good on the commitments of the partnership agreement with Kazakhstan and to show that it needs reforms, that it is not possible to continue with this dinosaur that no longer has time ahead and oppressing a country in which we absolutely need stability and democratic reforms.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Trilogues are currently underway, which is why I am in a certain place in place of Rose Thun, who co-authored today's resolution. We have sixteen recommendations, I am not able to cite everyone in such a short time, but I will pay attention to the most important ones. Firstly, the resolution calls on the Government of Kazakhstan to implement the recommendations of the UN Special Rapporteur on freedom, peaceful assembly and association. It calls on the Government of Kazakhstan to put an end to all forms of arbitrary detention, repression and harassment against human rights activists and civil society organisations. It also calls on the Government of Kazakhstan to review the changes to media and information law that have entered this year. Finally, it is very important, as this resolution points out, to apply Article 174 of the Penal Code on so-called incitement to social, national or clan discord. I would like to draw attention to the abuse of this article.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, for the past five years I have engaged extensively with Kazakhstani civil society. Standing in solidarity with persecuted human rights defenders, I’ve become familiar with the bleak human rights situation in the country. There are many worrying cases. I will highlight a few of them. Ablovas Dzhumayev was sentenced to three years simply for posting online his criticism of the Government. Aigul Akberdiyeva, a mother of four, is being persecuted in the same case – and I’m very disappointed that the final resolution we will vote on does not include her name, as her case is still pending and is just as relevant as the others. International observers who monitor such cases are expelled by the authorities without justification, as happened to Lyudmyla Voloshyna and Valeriy Yavtushenko. Judges such as the Chair of Aqtau City Court, Malik Kenzhaliev, can be punished when they do not follow orders. Similarly, others, like Aset Abishev, sentenced to four years in prison, and Almat Zhumagulov and Kenzhebek Abishev, sentenced respectively to eight and seven years, are punished under the pretext of the fight against extremism. They must all receive justice.

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this Parliament has a specific mandate and responsibility to its citizens and must be a beacon to Kazakhstan and our neighbours. The mechanism to allow these debates, bizarrely, is in the hands of unelected bureaucrats and although human rights of the people of Kazakhstan cannot be belittled, we have a much more pressing human rights issue right on our doorstep. With the presidential elections in Ukraine at the end of this month, the security and prosperity of the EU relies on EU standards being adhered to in countries that have an association agreement with the EU, countries that will potentially join the EU.  Reliable reports from human rights watchdogs warn of serious challenges to democracy when the current government, before an election, is putting undue pressure on independent TV channels like News One and Channel 112. If you do not have a free press, you cannot have a free and fair election. I put forward a resolution on freedom of the press in Ukraine, which was signed by 43 MEPs from all groups in this Parliament. The European People’s Party (EPP) bureaucracy blocked this. I hope they do not do this when it is represented next Strasbourg. We need to send an unequivocal message to Ukraine and the world on the need for freedom of the press.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Kazakhstan, which was the first central Asian country to win a seat among the non-permanent members of the UN Security Council, is unable to guarantee the peace and security of its own citizens internally. In this former Soviet republic, there is still no freedom of association, human rights activists and the LGBTI community, and dissenting voices are persecuted, detained and often subjected to torture and cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment. President Nazarbayev's regime is pursuing union leaders, including those who denounce the absolutely degrading working conditions of thousands of Kyrgyz immigrants, including children, and the threat of militant Islam is used as an excuse to restrict the religious freedom of minorities, including the Christian, who lives watched almost constantly and is fined for praying without the government's permission. The European Union, under the enhanced partnership and cooperation agreement, should urge the Kazakh authorities, as members of the Venice Commission, to comply with international human rights obligations and to call on the Government of Astana to release political prisoners and respect freedom that religion and belief.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Mimica, I think it is a very special case when we talk about human rights violations in Kazakhstan, bearing in mind that Kazakhstan enjoys a privileged relationship with the European Union, an important partnership agreement that distinguishes it as a giant in Central Asia in its strategic relations with the European Union.  But in Kazakhstan there has been a dreadsome democratic setback. A lifetime president, Nursultán Nazarbayev, whose leadership in Kazakhstan dates back to the time of the Soviet Union, and persecution of opponents to the concentration of power in the Nazarbayev family and clan, including Mukhtar Dzhakishev, which has been the subject of special attention by the United Nations Human Rights Committee and the Spanish authorities , because there has been diplomatic pressure to attempt the extradition of Kazakh opponents residing in European Union countries.  This case of Mukhtar Dzhakishev is particularly bleeding because he suffers torture and his fundamental rights in prison have been systematically violated, and has therefore received a clear message from the United Nations Human Rights Committee that the European Union should support diplomatically.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I think the debate has highlighted that there is a serious issue of protecting democratic rights in Kazakhstan. These countries, which managed or wanted, in any case, left the Soviet embrace, but unfortunately did not pass into democracy. They did not support the creation of a civil society, an area where democratic rights really work. On the other hand, however, the West has also supported these countries. And he took them because he had economic interests, because that is where the multinationals of Europe and America found a great opportunity to invest, to exploit the sources of wealth and, of course, to make super-profit. On this basis, then, the regimes remained, there were no democratic changes, and now everyone is coming to complain. This is the reality when one looks only at the way multinationals do of winning without, of course, caring about the development of democracy. We support and want to support democracy, which is why we also support this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
