text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Kazakhstan is not only one of the largest countries in the world, but also one of the richest in culture, history and traditions. Certainly peaceful coexistence between different ethnic and religious communities makes this country a model from which to learn. Today, however, all this diversity and cultural wealth are under great threat from anachronistic laws and repressive actions against anyone who thinks differently from the government line. More and more activists, members of the LGBTI community, journalists and trade union members are being targeted without any justification. Think of the protests of 2016, when a thousand people were arrested only for peacefully participating in the parade; let us think of the violence perpetrated by the authorities on 10 May against a group of demonstrators during a visit by a delegation from the European Parliament; think of Ardak Ashim, the blogger detained in a psychiatric hospital for inciting discord, through her posts, on the basis of Article 174 of the Penal Code, an article not yet reformed.  So I ask: what is the point of having a partnership and enhanced cooperation agreement which places the emphasis on democracy and the rule of law, if we then fail to reach the most important part, that of respect for freedom and fundamental rights?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this resolution is about the troublesome situation regarding human rights, democracy and the rule of law in Kazakhstan. The new Criminal Code has tightened the criminal laws being used to prosecute journalists, activists and opposition politicians. Freedom of expression is being restricted, with many receiving long—term prison sentences and being subjected to torture, ill treatment and psychological pressure in the detention facilities. The use of social networks is controlled and restricted by the authorities and social network users are being sentenced to imprisonment, while religious beliefs are being used by authorities as a pretext for arbitrary detention.  Therefore, I call on Kazakhstan to amend its legislation, in particular, the articles on criminal liability from the Criminal Code, which are overtly political in nature and I would recommend Kazakhstan apply the standards of the Council of Europe in its legal system.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this opportunity to discuss the human rights situation in Kazakhstan. As you know, the EU-Kazakhstan Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which has now been ratified by 25 EU Member States, provides the EU and Kazakhstan with a solid framework to advance our cooperation. It’s full ratification will enable us to further strengthen our cooperation, also on human rights, building on the existing regular dialogue with Kazakhstan. The human rights dialogue and the Justice and Home Affairs Subcommittee, last November, discussed, among other issues, the importance of an independent judiciary and legislative powers to ensure the effectiveness of the constitutional mechanisms of checks and balances, as well as zero tolerance to torture and ensuring independent monitoring of detention facilities. On that occasion, the European Union also raised concerns in relation to an independent media, freedom of expression and freedom of association and peaceful assembly. It remains important for Kazakhstan to continue to take steps to foster an enabling environment for civil society, human rights defenders, lawyers, trade unionists and journalists.  We are closely monitoring the human rights related developments in Kazakhstan, including in relation to the updated law on trade unions and its compatibility with ILO conventions, with international human rights standards and the impact on civil society of the law on the financing of NGOs. The EU-Kazakhstan Cooperation Committee in January agreed that the EU delegation and the Kazakh authorities would follow up on specific concerns raised and this is what we are doing. The rule of law will remain a key priority sector of the EU support in Kazakhstan through the new regional EU–Central Asia rule of law programme, which will begin in 2019.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Iran, in particular the situation of human rights defenders (2019/2611(RSP)).

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is well known that the Persian regime in Iran does not respect human rights, freedom of expression, freedom of religion, freedom of association, environmental commitment, which are self-evident to us but which can become synonymous with torture and the death penalty. In 2018, 273 people were executed in Iran. 2018 was also a difficult year for women in Iran. Pictures and videos spread all over the world, where women across the country had taken off their veil, sat on a stick and waved it like a flag in protest at the mandatory wearing hijab for women. It is an issue that has become a symbol of women's rights in general. Many were arrested and several have been sentenced to prison. According to Amnesty, 112 women activists have been detained. Many of them testify to ill-treatment and torture.  It is often women who are at the forefront of protests and calls for change in the country. It's a fight that for some ends up in jail or worse. It is therefore the duty of the outside world to support those women who are struggling to live free. We cannot stand by and watch this happen. Nasrin Sotoudeh has been sentenced to 33 years in prison and 148 lashes. With the five years to which she was previously sentenced, the total length of her prison sentence will be shockingly 38 years.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the I met Nasrin Sotudeh in Tehran in 2013 after her release, together with Jafar Panahi – both Sakharov Prize winners in 2012. She was released at the time. Now she has been behind bars since June 2018, as have many others. 38 years in prison, 148 lashes – this is not only an archaic verdict, but a huge scandal and, in fact, an attack on our personal interests and on people like Nasrin Sotudeh, who are among us who stand up for freedom. That is why the first thing we are calling for is the release of Nasrin Sotudeh, but not only of her, but also of environmental activists, of people who have taken to the streets because of social issues, of people who are behind bars for ethnic or religious reasons or who are journalists and bloggers. They have to get out of jail! We must ask this question again and again, and we must not let up on it. And now I say one more thing: in this situation, where human rights violations are once again escalating, to virtually suspend an eu-eu interparliamentary delegation with Iran – because the Iran delegation has not met since the end of 2018 – I find this quite scandalous and shameful for this House.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, we in the European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh, and she continues to work tirelessly, and with immense courage, to defend ordinary Iranians in the many instances – the too many instances – where their human rights are not respected. In particular, she was the lawyer of the many women protesting against the compulsory wearing of the hijab, before she herself was arrested again, and imprisoned again, and handed the preposterous sentence of 38 years in prison and 148 lashes. This is inhumane and unacceptable, and High Representative Mogherini should publicly join our call for the immediate release of Nasrin Sotoudeh. The obsession with Nasrin Sotoudeh on the part of the Islamic Republic’s judiciary and other authorities, and their insistence on silencing her, should only encourage us to hear what she is standing for – the universal human rights of all Iranians – and she deserves our unequivocal support.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: author. – Mr President, human rights defenders and trade union activists are arrested every day. They are arrested simply for campaigning for workers’ rights, for environmental standards and against the death penalty. The Iranian government is harassing BBC Persian journalists and their families. EU-Iranian dual nationals remain detained after a lack of due process and under vague charges. We heard this week that the prominent human rights lawyer, Nasrin Sotoudeh, was given a long prison sentence for defending dissidents and those brave woman who removed their hijab in public. By inflicting such a harsh sentence, the regime is making an example out of Nasrin and sending out a clear message that freedom of expression is not accepted.  I have a message for the Iranian authorities: we will not stop calling for the release of Nasrin Sotoudeh, Taher Ghadirian, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and all those who are unfairly detained and have been sentenced without a fair trial.  You cannot silence civil society. You cannot repress ideas, especially with the whole world watching. For our part, we will continue to support Iranians who want democracy and freedom for their country.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, the atrocious record of human rights in Iran is all too familiar to us in this House. Journalists and NGOs that do not conform to the wishes of the Government regime face routine harassment and repression, a pattern that extends to all groups and individuals that seek peacefully to oppose or protest against the actions of that brutal Government. These actions amount to a breach of all fundamental rights of assembly and expression. Freedom of religion is also vigorously repressed, as is demonstrated by the ongoing persecution of Christians, Baha’is and other minorities. In recent months, we have seen an intensification of the systematic campaign of house-church raids as Christians are arrested, and often violently interrogated, merely for the fact of peacefully exercising their religious beliefs. Several hundred Christians have been detained in recent months alone. Women’s rights are also severely curtailed in Iran, with even the most limited forms of dissent still being punished. In 2018, 39 women were arrested for protesting against the mandatory wearing of the hijab. Executions in the country continue to remain extremely high, with a figure standing at 273 for 2018. It does appear, however, that the November 2017 revision of the anti—narcotics law represents a significant improvement, with a dramatic reduction in death sentences. This is a fundamentalist regime that has robbed its people of their rights through its domestic policies, and has all too often impoverished them via its international isolation. So, clearly, this House must condemn that regime. It has done so for years, but so far, sadly, there has been little change to witness.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, Iran is one of the worst countries into the world for considering the rights and freedoms of its citizens. Last year Iran ranked second for the number executions – 273 of them. One may add numerous cases when a detained person was officially said to have committed suicide. Also last year tens of thousands of people all over Iran stood up against the rising costs of living, unpaid wages, corruption, political repressions and minority rights. They blamed the regime for wasting money on military and missiles, continuing costly expansion outside Iran, while ordinary people suffered more than ever. Our special concern is the fate of Nasrin Sotoudeh and her husband Reza Khandan, who just in January were sentenced to six years because of his peaceful protest against the forced wearing of hijabs, the fate of arrested environmental and trade union activists, and the fate of Maryam Akbari Monfared, who has already spent nine years in prison for so—called anti-God activities.  We call on the Iranian Government to release unconditionally all human rights defenders, prisoners of conscience, journalists and others. Yes, we once again call, urge and ask the Iranian authorities to behave and change. Can we really believe that Tehran’s rulers will change their behaviour, knowing very well that the regime cannot survive in conditions of free expression and an independent press? Therefore we urge our High Representative to publicly reaffirm that respect for human rights will be a core component and condition for any further development ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, the conviction of the Sakharov Prize winner has sparked a revolt in international public opinion. My colleagues have talked about the really incredible sentences that are being imposed on him.  The condemnation shows that the Iranian government is increasing the repression of activists and human rights defenders. My group recently held a hearing in the DROI subcommittee on eight environmental activists imprisoned in Iran, also mentioned in our resolution.  We are very concerned about these abuses and I would like to stress, as I have already done in this Chamber, that respect for human rights must be truly at the centre of our relations with Iran. I hope that Commissioner Mimica will convey this message to the High Representative. Finally, I would like to stress one point: we have requested the urgent dispatch of an ad hoc mission of the DROI sub-committee to Iran, and I hope that this mission will be authorised.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, 40 years of Islamic Republic of Iran have put us in absurd demand. What national security threat to Iran poses to the reading of the Gospel, of the Bible after all? Mind you, the Word of true spiritual peace in and through God. However, the wife of an Iranian preacher was sentenced to a double prison sentence of no less than ten years on this false charge. As a Christian, I am very concerned about the sharpening persecution of the Christian community in Iran. Do I ask too much when I ask the European Union to communicate and condemn this clearly towards the Iranian regime? In my home town of Apeldoorn, in the Netherlands, a Persian church meets freely. In Iran, Christians can no longer even fearlessly practice their faith in their own homes. At present, the public authority of the Iranian clergy has been severely diminished. The result of forty years of rule with hard faith coercion. The EU should not support this Iranian reign of terror, but all freedom-loving Iranian citizens, such as that courageous Mrs Nasrin Sotoudeh and her husband.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, arbitrary arrests, torture, prosecutions, fabricated trials, that is iran today. In 2015 it was 977 executions, in 2016 567 executions, in 2017 507 executions, in 2018 273 executions. Teenagers and women are also executed, often in a public and known drastic way – by hanging on construction cranes.  The case of Nasrin Sotoudo, an Iranian lawyer and advocate for many opponents of the regime, especially women, has shaken the world. In addition to her long sentence behind bars, she was sentenced to 148 lashes. We know the name Nasrin, winner of the Sakharov Prize. But I also want to bow to all those who are unjustly condemned and whose names are unknown. We are trying to list some of them in our resolution. Let's call things by their real names – the Tehran regime is a criminal regime.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! Iran is a terrorist state. A state that promotes terror here in Europe and in its own neighbourhood, but above all a state that is carrying out terror against its own people. Be it against activists who fight for environmental rights, workers' rights, religious or ethnic minorities or generally just people who allow themselves to be critical of the regime. Unfortunately, Iran is one of the countries on the planet that is fighting for first place in committing the most human rights violations. That is why it is also time for the European Union – if we really believe that we are pursuing a values-based foreign policy – to start to take it seriously in our treatment of the country. I believe that the Commission has placed too much emphasis on meeting Iran when it comes to the nuclear negotiations and giving them a free pass when it comes to the terror they are spreading both here in the European Union and in their own country. Let us now use sanctions as an effective weapon against the Iranians, including for their human rights violations.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to this debate, and I am glad for it, because when Mrs Mogherini and I debated the nuclear agreement here a few months ago, I felt, in particular, mrs Mogherini's relativisation of the horrors that the Tehran regime is realising. I am very glad that today we are calling the Iranian regime what we are supposed to call it. It is a totalitarian criminal regime that absolutely does not respect human rights, and it is good that there is a representative of the Commission, and I hope that Mrs Mogherini will handle the atmosphere that is here in the European Parliament and that economic and other interests cannot be changed for the protection of human rights. I join the resolution, I myself contributed there to the work on the suppression of ethnic and religious minorities in Iran. I think it is very good that we send a clear signal that because of the nuclear agreement with Iran, we are not willing to tolerate the regime's transgressions and crimes, crimes against human rights.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, the more I defend the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, and the more I defend the need to engage with Iran in all areas, the more I also contend that the EU must be vocal about human rights in Iran, about supporting all the brave men and women in Iran fighting for basic rights – like the women who gather every day, with white scarves, to fight the compulsory hijab. When the Committee on Foreign Affairs visited Iran in February of last year, we were confronted afterwards with the death in custody of environmental activist Kavous Seyed-Emami. Outrageous, outrageous! An affront against us – because she is a Sakharov Prize laureate – is the sentence against Nasrin Sotoudeh. And, as many speakers have mentioned here, many others are also suffering in Iran and we can’t tolerate that. The sentence against Nasrin Sotoudeh is also, and primarily, an affront against the Iranian civilisation. It’s outrageous. We cannot accept it and High Representative Federica Mogherini has to be absolutely vocal about that. (Applause)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Who remembers Nasrin Sotoudeh? That Iranian human rights lawyer was our laureate for the Sakharov Prize in 2012. Nasrin couldn't take it herself, because she wasn't allowed out of the country. Iran was one big prison, and it still is. Nasrin faces up to 33 years in prison and faces 148 lashes. 33 years in prison and 148 lashes for taking on women protesting the requirement to wear a headscarf. The harshest punishment for an activist in years. It confirms what people in the Iranian civil society often tell me. Tehran is stepping up repression. The trials are often a joke, but the penalties are by no means. Do you know why Iran keeps becoming a three-star? Because it gets away with it. Tehran feels completely free to lock up opponents and treat them unusually harshly. As long as we do not make it clear to Tehran that this will have consequences, Commissioner, nothing will change.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Nasrin Sotoudeh has been sentenced to 38 years in prison and 148 lashes. Nasrin is a wonderful woman, sakharov prize winner, and perfectly embodies the definition of a defender of human rights. His imprisonment took place just as he was carrying out this activity, with an arrest last June. This verdict, as well as the whole process that first led to Nasrin's arrest and then conviction, are unacceptable and can only be explained in the light of the continuing harassment of journalists, lawyers, activists and human rights defenders, who have been convicted only for dared to speak out against the government. I call on Iran to release Nasrin immediately, as well as all those imprisoned for political reasons.  Ladies and gentlemen, as we all know, we have important political work to do, including the hard-won defence of the nuclear agreement. But in the face of such flagrant violations of human rights, we must ring alarm bells. The need for high-level political cooperation with Tehran must not prevent us from saying clearly and loudly that certain violations cannot and must not be accepted.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am not dealing with Iran, but it is dealing with security issues – for this reason, participating in an election observation mission in Pakistan or participating in a debate on Afghanistan. What worries me the most today is the lack of coherence between the various documents and the debates. I would remind you that on Tuesday we talked about Afghanistan, we talked about Iran on this occasion, and about pakistan. On the one hand, the security threat, on the other hand, from Pakistan, the migration processes. We are talking today about human rights, about the abuse of various criminal laws against Iranian citizens, against journalists, against women. We are talking about the drama of these people. I would like to stress that, in order for European Union policy, Parliament's policy to be effective, we must show greater determination, greater consistency in the documents submitted to the various governments, and also pay attention to the interdependences that occur in the geographical parts we are discussing. I therefore call for greater consistency, more determination, more coherence.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the situation of press freedom in Iran is very concerning. I am particularly worried about the BBC Persian Service journalists who have become a target of the Iranian authorities. The persecution against BBC journalists started in 2009 when the service launched satellite television. However, recent measures have escalated this persecution against the journalists and their families. The persecution includes a gender dimension, as it is directed primarily against women staff and their families. Iran’s record on the treatment of women is infamously poor. The recent sentencing of the human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh to148 lashes and 38 years in prison is particularly despicable. It comes shortly after the appointment of a new hard-line head of judiciary. As the UN investigator on human rights in Iran, Javaid Rehman, said, patterns of intimidation, arrest, prosecution and ill-treatment of human rights defenders, lawyers and labour rights activists signal an increasingly severe state response.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, there are already countless times that I have intervened here in this Plenary to denounce the lack of democracy, the disregard for human rights and the atrocities and crimes against humanity committed by the Ayatollah regime to its own citizens.  The truth is that iran's repressive regime can no longer hide the fact that Iran is the most repressive country in the Middle East and that it executes more people per capita than any other in the world. Human rights defenders are no exception to this bloodthirsty eagereing of the Tehran regime, with the revolutionary guards' corps murdering dozens and apprehending thousands, including those brave women facing prison, torture and rape for peacefully only asking for democracy and gender equality in their country. The Iranian regime is a stain of shame for international society and for all of humanity. How long will we accept this monstrous regime that behaves with its leaders and followers as true animals of the worst kind? Ladies and gentlemen, after forty years of a brutal clerical dictatorship, today 80 million Iranians are fed up and say, like us: enough!

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, there are very many human rights violations being committed by the Iranian regime, as we’ve heard this morning, but I’d like to focus on one group of people. The Iranian authorities have been systematically targeting BBC Persian staff, and are moving on to the staff of other European broadcasters as well. Most of those staff are based in London, and their families in Iran have also been targeted. Many of those affected are EU-Iranian dual nationals, mostly British Iranians. One hundred and fifty-two staff have been subjected to an unfair asset-freezing injunction since 2017, and their families have been subjected to arbitrary arrest, travel bans and harassment. I would particularly like to raise awareness about the sexualised defamation campaigns being waged against brave female journalists at BBC Persian. I would call on the EU no longer to be silent about this attack on European women, European journalists. We have a duty and a responsibility to defend free journalism. I welcome today’s resolution, coming as it does in the same week that these concerns are being raised in Geneva at the UN Human Rights Council.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to join my colleagues in coming to an agreement on the regime in Iran. It is indeed a regime of terror that crushes its citizens, executing, imprisoning and toning them. Any opposition to this regime is immediately punished, human rights are virtually non-existent. We have repeatedly devoted our attention to Iran, and I think that we must stand up for free Iranians who want regime change. We must support them, and I would like to ask you, Commissioner, to tell Mrs Mogherini that the Opinion of the European Parliament is different from her view of leniency towards the Iranian regime. We unequivocally oppose the policy of this regime of terror and want to ask you, Commissioner, to change the position of the European Commission in this way. The European Parliament has a different view.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, just a few months ago, on 10 December 2018, the international community marked the 70th anniversary of the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. On the occasion, High Representative Federica Mogherini, published a declaration on behalf of the European Union, in which she emphasised that support for human rights defenders, including women human rights defenders, is at the core of the EU external human rights policy, and one of its major priorities. A few days later, this commitment was underlined by Honourable Members of the European Parliament during a debate on the Iranian human rights defender Nasrin Sotoudeh, who just a few days earlier, at the time, was convicted and sentenced in connection with her work to promote universally recognised rights. Our deep concern at her conviction was expressed immediately in a statement.  Our commitment to support human rights defenders is there 365 days, throughout the year, and not only on 10 December. Indeed, as part of our diplomacy, we closely follow the human rights situation in countries around the world, including Iran. A cardinal aspect of this task is working to support the work of human rights defenders and ensure, as far as possible, that they are not subjected to harassment or detention.  With respect to Iran, this extends to closely following the situation of Ms Sotoudeh and other individuals, including, for example, the group of eight environmentalists who were detained in January last year and who are facing extremely serious charges. In Iran and in other countries, human rights defenders, including human rights lawyers, do invaluable work. This includes providing legal representation to members of vulnerable groups, representing juvenile offenders facing the death penalty, working to protect women or members of ethnic and religious minorities. All too often, however, this work is met with repression or convictions and imprisonment on security-related charges. This is inconsistent with the Universal Declaration and with the International Covenant on civil and political rights, which Iran ratified in 1975 and which commits Iran to ensure that no one shall be subjected to arbitrary arrests or detention, no one shall be deprived of his liberty, except on such grounds and in accordance with such procedures as are established by law.  As clearly reflected in the latest conclusions on Iran, adopted by the Council on 4 February, while we are committed to the full and effective implementation of the joint comprehensive plan of action, the European Union policy on Iran is based on a balanced and comprehensive approach, critical when there are these divergences and cooperative in case of shared interests. In line with this approach, the European Union has repeatedly called on Iran to provide human rights defenders with an open, stable environment in which to conduct their work. The European Union has also consistently raised individual human rights cases with the Iranian authorities at all levels, including in the framework of the EU–Iran a high-level dialogue.  We are strong supporters of the mandate of the UN special rapporteur for the situation of human rights in Iran and encourage the Iranian authorities to grant him access to the country.  Finally, our Member States have also raised the case during their own bilateral contacts with the Iranian authorities. We strongly believe that these efforts have contributed to certain positive developments that we have noted in recent years, including the decision to amend Iran’s anti-narcotics legislation in November 2017, which has resulted in a dramatic reduction in drug-related executions and which, in itself, is a positive step forward in human rights. We are continuing to advocate for further improvements in this regard, including an immediate moratorium on the execution of juvenile offenders. We continue to call for the release of all Iranian human rights defenders. Those who are detained should be afforded timely access to a lawyer of their own choosing, be allowed to communicate with their family members, have access to adequate medical care and not be subject to any form of mistreatment.  We are encouraged by the attention paid to this issue by Members of the European Parliament and we will continue our effort to work together with you in order to promote a better environment for human rights defenders across the world, including in Iran.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner Mimica. Thank you for sounding the same voice to members and to your voice. I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Guatemala (2019/2618(RSP).

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: author. – Mr President, this urgency was called because of our concern about threats posed by the Guatemalan Government to the protection of human rights and specifically its decision to withdraw support for the International Commission against Impunity (CICIG). CICIG has played a vital role in supporting Guatemalan legal and judicial institutions that are crucial to upholding the rule of law and to ensuring the legal and physical safety of human rights defenders, including Sakharov finalist Lolita Chávez.  It is deeply concerning that the Guatemalan Government is showing contempt for its own people by colluding in acts of intimidation. We are also convinced that changes proposed to the national reconciliation law pose a significant threat to the rule of law in Guatemala, and would drastically undermine the important progress achieved by CICIG.  We urge the Commission to swiftly disburse the EUR 5 million already earmarked for CICIG and stand ready for further support. Our negotiations were conducted in a good cooperative spirit, so it’s disappointing and somewhat mystifying, if I’m honest, to hear that the EPP will now abstain on this resolution. But we still expect a wide majority to support it and its strong wording of condemnation for democratic and human rights breaches in Guatemala.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, democracy and the rule of law are under attack in Guatemala. On the one hand, human rights defenders continue to be persecuted, both physically and through new restrictive laws and farce trials, and often there are the interests of multinationals to deal with these cowardly attacks, and on the other hand we have – or rather, we had – the International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala, which is the protagonist of crucial work in the fight against corruption and in strengthening the rule of law.  Unfortunately, however, after presenting new investigations into the government party's illicit funding for the election campaign, the committee also came under attack and was ousted. Perfect timing: right before the election. To add to the damage, Congress is passing a law that would extend amnesty for crimes such as genocide and torture committed during armed conflict. If Congress passes this law, war criminals would immediately return to sow violence across the country, not to mention reprisals.  It is therefore our duty to use the means at our power to dissuade Congress from adopting this amnesty, to ensure that the Committee against Impunity is reinstated and to protect human rights defenders from attacks by multinationals.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Author. – Mr President, for the second time this Parliament is going to issue an emergency resolution on the serious human rights situation in Guatemala. The European Union is making great efforts in international cooperation with this Central American country. However, the setback in fundamental rights and the rule of law is becoming increasingly worrying. The growing role of the military in government is driving reforms such as the National Reconciliation Act that will end up killing criminals. The persecution of CICIG increases as prosecutions by the Prosecutor's Office are reaching senior officials and even the president of the government itself. Twenty-six human rights defenders killed in the country in 2018, to which four journalists must also be added. These are crimes that are mostly left unpunished. And, despite international support, people like Lolita Chavez still can't return to their country and Bernardo Caal is still in prison without a fair trial. It is only necessary to remind the Government of Guatemala that, as this Resolution says that we are going to adopt, it will be necessary to assess its suspension as a member of the European Union-Central America Agreement if the human rights safeguard clauses are not respected.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, the International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala has done an excellent job in its eleven years of operation, helped to investigate more than a hundred cases, convict more than three hundred people and present thirty-four legal reforms.  Everything was fine until the commission involved relatives of President Jimmy Morales. When he put the spotlight on his own, the commission ceased to be useful.  Morales is surrounded by a nationalist rhetoric that we already know and shows that even if it does not reach the criminal levels of the Venezuelan regime, reactionary populism can be as harmful to institutions as Bolivarian.  The case of Guatemala reminds us of the benefits of international cooperation and governance, with human rights and democracy as basic principles.  The European Union must press for a cessation of human rights violations, for further investigation of corruption and for impunity to never return to Guatemala.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Author. "Mr. President, thank you for your efforts in pronunciation. We are talking about a country, Guatemala, which is an extremely poor country with enormous inequalities; a country with a very large subculture of violence and a very dangerous drug trafficking presence. We are talking about a country with too much corruption and we are talking about a country that has – yes, it is true, you have all said so - serious bankruptcies of the rule of law and human rights.  But we are talking about a friendly country, a country with which we cooperate, a country that we want and want to help, that will hold a very important election next June and that has high hopes that this political change will truly make a better country. Europe wants to help these people. Europe wants to help that country. And it does so today, yes, condemning a government that is operating in serious human rights failures, especially with the expulsion of the International Commission against Impunity, which is the most important United Nations agency. And we do this by also warning him that there will be sanctions for that country if it does not move in the line of freedom and democracy.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, I think that the greatest happiness that the European Union has is the principles. Principles on which it is built and built. This is the principle of democracy and the rule of law. Unfortunately, Guatemala has not experienced and is not experiencing these two principles, and unless something changes with the regime there, it will not experience them in the future. The international mission operating there has long highlighted the problems of corruption and, most often, corruption linked to the government and the regime there. It is completely inconceived that many human rights activists who have in recent years drawn attention to corruption linked to the government dictatorship there have either died or disappeared under mysterious circumstances. Yes, this country is poor, this country has a lot of social problems, this country is socially, I would say, divided. There is no unity, and it is precisely that in recent years its leaders have built their policies on nationalism, and in an attempt to incite hatred against those who criticize them, it confirms them that people are not rebelling enough precisely against the fact that human rights are being violated. That is why we want to call on the European Commission and the international community with this resolution to do more to promote them and to try to change the political situation there.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I had the privilege of representing this Parliament in signing the Peace Agreements in Guatemala and we all want Guatemala to make progress on respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the fight against impunity.  However, I am not convinced that this resolution reliablely represents the real situation in the country.  In any event, I am interested, Mr President, in emphasizing one of the aspects contained in this Resolution, and it is the need for a real assessment of the impact of its work on the judicial field, as regards the political, economic and institutional aspects, and , above all, Mr President, to look into the fact that an institution which had broad majority support from the outset, both inside and outside the country, has gradually weakened.  (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Salafranca, I, in truth, am stunned. When you talk about human rights in places outside Venezuela, you change your judgment. How is it possible that there was a joint motion for a resolution signed with the EPP Group, that there have been hyper-important interventions by the EPP Group here today, and that you say that they are going to abstain or say that it is not such a profound solution? Frankly, I'm surprised by this hypocrisy. Would you therefore be prepared to vote in favour of this joint motion for a resolution?

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Miranda, it seems to me that the word hypocrisy is a word that is not compatible with respect and parliamentary courtesy. Here we make use of freedom of expression.  And, Mrs Miranda, I tell you that, by word, man is superior to the animal, but by silence he overcomes himself. You have missed a very remarkable opportunity to overcome yourself, which is not very difficult.  (He refused to have Xabier Benito Ziluaga ask him a question under the "blue card" procedure.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, unfortunately we are again today, here, talking about a situation of a retreat of the rule of law in a Country in Latin America. Yesterday we had the opportunity to debate a resolution on Nicaragua here, and incisive statements were made here condemning what has been a very negative development of the regime in Nicaragua, and today we are facing a different situation, but it points to very close situations. In fact, what has been progressively underway in Guatemala is a negative development towards the progressive disregard for fundamental rules of the rule of law which have already resulted in the decision to call into question the permanence of an international Commission against impunity which had guaranteed very significant advances, among other things, in the fight against corruption. , and now in this view of moving towards an amnesty which is incompatible with fundamental principles of law.  I would like to make a very specific reference here to the indigenous peoples who in Guatemala have historically been vilified by their fundamental rights and who should deserve a special word of attention from this European Parliament.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we are very concerned about the situation in Guatemala: attacks on human rights defenders, indigenous peoples and social organizations do not stop. In addition, we condemn the cancellation of the mandate of the International Commission against Impunity. That is why our support for its director , who has been criticized for reporting corruption cases of the president's brother and the president's son , and the European embassies, especially the Swedish Embassy. And how would admitting the Reconciliation Act, which would mean getting the worst human rights violators out of prison in the civil war? It's like a call to violence and war. Or the NGO's proposal of law, which is intended only to restrict their freedom of expression and assembly.  Guatemala is a militarized country where the rule of law disappears day after day. And our concern is also for human rights defenders: for our dear Lolita, for the defenders who are in prison, so that they can return to their country in peace. She and all advocates must be protected, because unfortunately what the Government of Guatemala wants is to continue to preserve the privileges of a few wealthy families who believe the country's owners.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Obsessive sexism is perhaps the most onerous disease in this Parliament, which spoils a few sensible initiatives and makes things worse in the case of poor and harmful ones. The first point states that the European Parliament is concerned about the increasing number of killings, in particular against women. But in Guatemala, the overwhelming majority of homicides involve men. You write about more than six hundred murders of women, you do not write about more than five thousand murders of men. You write that the number of female homicides has increased by 8%, but the number of male homicides has increased similarly. Once again, you take the data out of context and juggle it to fit your preconding thesis – even with regard to human rights defenders, the European Parliament values women's lives above all, because we read: 'renews the demand for the protection of human rights defenders – especially women'. How are women in particular? What does this mean? I am pleased that this term is coming to an end, and I hope that in the next term of office, feminazists who value the lives of some people above others, simply because they are of a different gender, will no longer be majority.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There is no doubt that the situation of human rights violations in Guatemala is alarming, especially with regard to attacks on human rights defenders and journalists and violence against women, which has been steadily increasing over the last few years.  From my point of view, the plans of the Guatemalan Congress to adopt a new law establishing a general amnesty for those who have committed serious human rights violations during the past armed conflict are particularly worrying. I believe that such a right could significantly endanger the safety of victims as well as of the witnesses, judges or experts involved in these cases. I believe that the proposed law is not only a serious violation of human rights, but also an attempt to pave the way for a broader strategy of impunity for human rights violations in Guatemala. I would like to stress with firmness that such actions are met with strong and fierce opposition from the European Union, which is why I call on the Guatemalan Congress to reject the proposed law.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, Guatemala was making progress in prosecuting human rights and corruption cases due in significant part to the collaboration of the Attorney General’s Office with the United Nations-backed International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG). However, that collaboration is now suspended, further to the decision of President Jimmy Morales not to renew the mandate of CICIG at the expiration in September 2019, and the prohibition on CICIG Commissioner Velásquez from re-entering the country. I want to highlight the progress that has been made in the fight against impunity in Guatemala, thanks to the efforts of CICIG. I now ask President Morales to reconsider his decision to deny a visa to lead prosecutor Iván Velásquez. Guatemala’s gang-related violence is a primary factor prompting people to leave the country. Guatemala suffers from high levels of impunity, partly because criminal proceedings against powerful actors often suffer unreasonably long delays, and intimidation against judges and prosecutors and corruption within the justice system continues to be a problem.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I join those colleagues who are calling for tough action against Guatemala. It is clear that the situation in this country is getting worse. As a former Minister of Justice, I am interested in how corruption is fought here. I must say that what other colleagues here have already said, that the International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala, the so-called CICIG, is effectively being liquidated by the current government, is extremely wrong. It's an extremely dangerous signal, and we should take a hard stand against it. A country where corruption is rampant, where violence against the population occurs, where unexplained murders occur, needs an institution that has international prestige and that fights serious forms of crime and corruption. If we merely stand by and watch the current government liquidate the CICIG, I think that this will be very wrong, and it should be reflected in our negotiations, Commissioner, that we are very dissatisfied with the government's approach to the rule of law, to the fight against corruption and to this commission.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since her adolescence María Magdalena Cuc Choc, now thirty-nine years old, has been fighting for the defence of El Estor, a magical place, a land of Mayan Q'eqchi' communities. For many years it has become the scene of an intense conflict between oil and mining companies and the indigenous population for the control of natural resources. Like the case of El Estor, many others are the conflicts over natural resources in Guatemala, where human rights defenders always pay with their lives: 26 killed in 2018 alone, a 136 % increase compared to 2017. To further destabilise the country, the unilateral announcement by the government of the end of the mandate of the International Commission against Impunity, born out of an agreement with the United Nations in 2006. Above all, there is the absurd proposal to amend the Law of National Reconciliation, which would extend amnesty for all crimes committed by government authorities, including crimes against humanity.  In the light of these events, the risk of the situation precipitated is very high, especially in view of this summer's presidential elections. I call on the Guatemalan Government to put an immediate end to the abuses against indigenous activists and communities and on the European Union to demand compliance with the human rights clause in the Association Agreement, otherwise we will never be credible towards the citizens of Guatemala.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, as a human rights lawyer, my heart is always deeply touched by the kind of stories we heard today about people who, for political reasons, are subjected to arbitrary criminal proceedings, and about political prisoners in detention being abused or even tortured. These stories today took us to Kazakhstan, to Iran and to Guatemala. But, Commissioner, could you please brief us on the situation of political prisoners in France and in Spain? What is happening to those hundreds of people, or thousands maybe, who, during the mass demonstrations, were detained by Macron’s authorities? How are they doing? What do we know about their legal situation? And what about those political prisoners who were detained because they were fighting for the self-determination of Catalonia? I wonder if you could give us a brief or detailed introduction to their situation?

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, after being in Nicaragua two months ago to check on the ground the allegations of human rights violations, the repression of the orteguista opposition against the Nicaraguan people, is that now a neighbouring country of its own, Guatemala, which apparently somehow followed the path of progress and the restoration of democratic life in the country, reverses its path and decides , through its parliament, to pass a law that could jeopardise the very Law of National Reconciliation passed 23 years ago and which allowed peace to be sealed and society to be pacified. This is, Mr President, the adoption last month of an amnesty law for crimes against humanity committed during the Guatemalan civil war and the possible adoption of the reform of the NGO Law which will limit the work of these organisations in the country.  The European Union cannot only condemn the attack on human rights defenders and indigenous peoples, but must clearly and unequivocally demonstrate its concern for the adoption of these laws, in particular by calling into question the very maintenance of the association agreement with Central America and the agreement of political dialogue and cooperation with Guatemala, until respect for human rights in guatemala is restored.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, Guatemala is a poor country that has enormous potential but unfortunately does not make much use of it. I think that this country has gone in the right direction, but unfortunately it has gone a long way afterwards and the situation is really deteriorating radically. Respect for human rights has serious cracks, and impunity, which should have been eradicated by the commission, is once again coming to the fore. I think that we must properly condemn this situation, also the human rights violations that I have mentioned, but also the violence against women. If my colleague Sośnierz here has talked about the increase in violence against men, I do not think that women are committing this violence against men in Guatemala. I don't think we can relativize certain concepts in this way. It is important that we use the instruments that we have, whether it is international pressure or, of course, the economic role that we can see in European development aid. We should definitely press the authorities in Guatemala.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to address this House on the political and human rights situation in Guatemala. The European Union and Guatemala have a solid bilateral relationship based on mutual commitment and trust. That is precisely why it is important to say that we are concerned by the weakening of the rule of law materialised by the recent attacks on the fight against corruption, notably the decision by the Government to terminate the activity of the International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG) and also by recent parliamentary initiatives that could reduce the democratic space as well as generate impunity for crimes against humanity committed during the civil war. The European Union has been a staunch supporter of the CICIG both financially and politically. Over the last ten years, the European Union has provided EUR 22 million to the anti—corruption UN body. For 2019, the last year of the current mandate and in very difficult conditions, our contribution amounts to EUR 5 million. Achievements in the fight against corruption and impunity have been impressive, also contributing to the reduction of criminality in Guatemala. Despite constant attacks, CICIG is very popular, admired and respected in Guatemala as the people know that corruption severely undermines the institutions, the rule of law and ultimately the country’s democracy. So let me repeat this: the European Union stands by Guatemala; the European Union stands by its commitment to the fight against corruption; the European Union stands by CICIG. We do of course continue to support all efforts against corruption by the Guatemalan judicial institutions. They play a crucial role in the fight against impunity. The separation of powers and respect for judicial rulings is paramount as it is a cornerstone of the rule of law. The overall security situation in Guatemala has recently improved. However, ensuring the protection of human rights defenders and other activists and avoiding any further deaths and attacks is urgent and essential. Human rights defenders paid a heavy toll last year with a doubling in the number of casualties according to human rights organisations. People from vulnerable groups, such as indigenous community leaders, environmentalists or LGBTIs, have been particularly targeted.  Finally, and while fully respecting the country’s democratic process, we want to express our concerns about two bills currently being discussed in Guatemala’s Parliament, as Mr Ignazio Corrao rightly pointed out. The first would reduce the space for civil society organisations by restricting their conditions for registration and operation, and undermining the democratic role played by a free and open civil society. The second draft bill would reform the national reconciliation law adopted after the Civil War and give absolute impunity for crimes against humanity. Yesterday our EU delegation in Guatemala, along with Embassies of the European Union Member States present in the country and together with the US and Canada, spoke out publicly against that bill. I’m glad to see that yesterday, Congress did not find a quorum to discuss that project for an amnesty, but we must remain vigilant as it is not totally off the table.  The country will have elections later this year in June and we have the highest respect for the electoral period Guatemala is entering. Elections are an important moment, where the people unite to debate, compare visions and ultimately elect their leadership. They should be used to enhance democracy and the rule of law and not to put in question the basic tenets or all the hard-gained advances over the last decades.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. (The meeting was suspended at 11.47 am pending the start of the vote) Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – Taking into account previous resolutions on Iran, in particular in the case of Nasrin Sotoudeh since December 2018 and on imprisoned EU citizens and Iran since May 2018, it is necessary to act promptly with a view to the unconditional release of innocent people who have stood up for democracy in Iran.  The motion for the resolution applies to human rights defenders, including Nasrin Sotoudeh, Reza Khandana and women's rights activist Farhada Meysami and all prisoners detained and sentenced for expressing their right to free speech and peacefully protesting for human rights and abolishing the death penalty.  Furthermore, the Iranian authorities are expected to amend Article 48. law on criminal procedure in the country to give all those arrested access to a lawyer of their choice throughout the trial so that a transparent and fair trial can be ensured. We also call on Iran to stop criminalizing and baselessly accusing women who are women's rights activists and who peacefully protest against the mandatory wearing of the hijab. The Iranian authorities must ensure the smooth performance of the activities of those advocating for human rights without threats and intimidation. It is inadmissible for human rights defenders, journalists and other workers who promote personal and political freedom through democratic instruments, i.e. peaceful protests, to face harassment, unfounded arrests and detention.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I have two announcements first. We have the pleasure of welcoming a delegation from the Parliament of Canada, chaired by Scott Simms. The delegation is in Strasbourg to take part in the fortieth Committee on Parliamentary Cooperation between the European Union and Canada. Relations between the European Union and Canada have been significantly strengthened in recent years thanks to the conclusion of the Strategic Partnership Agreement and the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement, and prime minister Trudeau's speech in 2017. These landmark agreements are not only an expression of the common values of Canada and the European Union, but have also led to cooperation in a wide range of areas and to numerous joint initiatives to promote multilateral cooperation, peace, democracy and the rule of law. Your presence in this House also symbolises the deepening of interparliamentary relations between our parliaments, which has already been expressed in a joint declaration in 2017. It is therefore a great honour for us to welcome you to our Parliament in the most warm estimating. I hope you have had successful meetings and wish you all the best for your stay. (Applause) Before we proceed to the vote, I would also like to welcome, on behalf of all of us, the delegation of Ukrainian MePs who have come to attend the ninth meeting of the EU-Ukraine Parliamentary Association Committee. This meeting is also the last of this parliamentary term. Dear friends from Ukraine, as you know very well, this Parliament has paid particular attention to the situation in your country over the past five years. (Applause) We have done this both to support the reform process in the spirit of the aspirations of the people of Majdan Square and to defend your territorial integrity and sovereignty. Our support was also recently expressed by the awarding of the Sakharov Prize 2018 to Oleg Sentzow. We are very pleased that you are here today with us and hope that you had a very successful meeting! Welcome again! (Applause) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which When I last chaired the vote, I announced that, right now, before the election, I am only taking speeches that really focus on the Rules of Procedure. I will therefore ask everyone to mention the Rules of Procedure. You can rest assured that I have great sympathy for all your concerns, at least for most of them, but that it has nothing to do with them. I will maintain this principle. (Applause and heckling in the hall) However, I would like to make an exception, because there has not been a Conference of Presidents today. I would therefore like to give Mr Lamberts the opportunity to present something that he wanted to present today in the Conference of Presidents. Otherwise, I will not allow speeches which do not relate to the Rules of Procedure.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, under Article 11, paragraph 1, of our internal regulation, I would like to draw the attention of the whole House to this article which says that Members' behaviour is inspired by mutual respect, based on the values and principles enshrined in the treaties, particularly in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Members, including our Speaker, preserve the dignity of Parliament and do not damage its reputation. The President of this Parliament, Antonio Tajani, yesterday made statements in the Italian media, in which he found positive elements for the fascist regime of Benito Mussolini in Italy. In this way, it accredits the thesis that, in the end, there may be good in regimes that destroy democracy. I think that such statements are unworthy, unworthy of the president of a parliament!  These statements, ladies and gentlemen, are unworthy of the President of the first transnational parliament in the history of humanity, the Parliament of a European Union which has been put on track so that we will never again in Europe relive the fascist regimes that have marred the history of this continent. I therefore ask the President of Parliament to withdraw his statements, otherwise he must withdraw himself.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: You will understand that we are not having a debate on this. Mrs Zimmer has also spoken, referring to what I said about the fact that there was no meeting of the Conference of Presidents today.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Unfortunately, it was decided yesterday that the Conference of Presidents will be cancelled today. Yesterday afternoon I became aware of this radio interview, which my colleague Mr Lamberts has already mentioned, and I would certainly have mentioned it this morning at a conference of Presidents. That is why, on behalf of my group, I made a statement and a press release this morning, that we, as a group, are calling for the resignation of the President of the European Parliament, because it is not possible (applause) for this democratically elected Parliament, which has a very specific mandate, namely to prevent hatred, fascism and anti-Semitism from ever again shaping the atmosphere in relations between our countries, a man who trivialises the time of Mussolini, who pretends to be Mussolini someone, who is only at a certain point in time. I would like to remind you that there are people sitting here in this Parliament whose parents – fathers, mothers – have already been imprisoned in the first year of Mussolini's reign. That here in Parliament we keep referring to Spinelli and others who, with the Ventotene Manifesto, laid the foundations for the founding of the European Union and for the Treaty of Rome .... (Tumult in the Hall) (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Zimmer, you no longer have the floor. (Tumult in the room.) Mrs Zimmer, I call you to order. Group chairmen are elected because they have special skills. This also means that you can stick to a certain speaking time. You spoke for almost two minutes. Mr Weidenholzer is now speaking on behalf of Mr Bullmann, chairman of the group.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the President Tajani yesterday made irritating statements about Mussolini's role. Many people in Europe perceived it as trivialising and relativizing this dark period in Italian and European history. Unfortunately, this is not the first time that our President has made a public appearance through idiosyncratic interpretations of history. None of this is consistent with our basic understanding and contradicts the understanding of the bipartisanship of this office. Yesterday, Mr Bullmann criticised Tajani's statements and expressed our concern. On behalf of our group, we call on the President to take a position immediately and in detail on what he has said, and we reserve the right to take further steps. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: On the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, Mr Gonzalez Pons.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, there is a law of the politician on election campaigning that says: "Don't let the truth spoil a good debate for you." The truth is...

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Forenza, I call on you to leave this place.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, I said that there is a law of the politician on election campaigning that says: "Don't let the truth spoil a good debate for you." There's a law by the populist politician in the campaign that says, "Don't let the truth spoil a good show for you." My parliamentary group, the People's Group, condemns without any reservation fascism, Francoism, Nazism and communism. Have absolutely no doubt about the position of our parliamentary group.  Antonio Tajani is a Democrat, he has been until yesterday, he is today and he will be tomorrow. We all know him. Most of us here have voted on him and we have all had him as president, attending to our discussions and leading our deliberations. And Antonio Tajani shares, as he has said publicly, with my parliamentary group, the condemnation of fascism, the condemnation of Francoism, the condemnation of Nazism and the condemnation of communism.  Mr. Lamberts, I've listened to you and I haven't been nervous. And I heard him last Monday opposing us debating political prisoners in Venezuela and then defending the rights of fish in fish farms, and I did so with the same respect that I listened to him this morning.  Having said that, Mr President, we can all make a mistake in the media and we can all be misrepresented in the media. Antonio Tajani has explained under what circumstances those words he does not defend occurred, so my parliamentary group understands — and I say so – that we have no right to bring the election campaign to this House... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr González Pons, you do not have the floor any more. It has been almost three minutes, and I asked Ms Zimmer to end. We cannot have a long discussion on that point.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, formerly Rule 21. I would like to tell you, however, that you too are wrong about your position as President of the House at the moment, because the seriousness of what happened yesterday goes far beyond the reference to a Regulation of the European Parliament.  I would just like to point out that the fascist regime began in Italy with the famous bivouac speech, in which it was said that it wanted to turn Parliament into a bivouac of hand-in-hand... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Forenza, you no longer have the floor. I will take the floor out of you. Your microphone is turned off, and volume doesn't make it any better. I have clearly set out the rules that I have changed. It is at the discretion of the President, and I have insisted that the Conference of Presidents has failed today and that I am therefore giving room. Otherwise, I shall give the floor only on a point of order and not on the continuation of this brief debate that we now have. Mrs Miranda has also raised a point of order. But the same applies to you.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, I demand respect and silence, please. President Tajani's words contravene, of course, the article ...  (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: No, Ms Miranda, this is exactly what we will not do. It is not a question of respect. You do not have the floor any more. Please sit down.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, I rise under Rule 1 on behalf of all colleagues in this Parliament. Please can we get on with the vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Carver, I would like to thank Mr Carver for his That was clear on a point of order. Nevertheless, I must allow further points of order. Mr. Sonierz!

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I just briefly wanted to address it. When it comes to democracy and Altiero Spinelli, in one sentence, we cannot combine that. Altiero Spinelli speaks in his manifesto from Ventotene about the dictatorship of the revolutionary party, so what do you rely on? If anyone has the right to talk about a democrat... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Sonierz, I would like to thank Mr Sonierz for his work on this This is not about interpretations of politics, but about the Rules of Procedure. I shall give the floor to Mr Verhofstadt, who has yet to speak on this debate on the Conference of Presidents, once I have dealt with the other points of order. Who would like to raise a point of order? Mrs Jamet, I would like to thank Mrs Jamet for her work

name: France JAMET
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, more seriously, solemnly and briefly, I would like to inform you that today we are going to vote on the resolution on the negotiations with the United States...  (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Jamet, I would like to thank Mrs Jamet for her work This is not about individual content. I will take the floor out of you. You have not raised a point of order. Mr Viotti, I would like to thank Mr Viotti for his

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, I am speaking on the basis of Rule 21 and I would ask you to give me the floor, because President Tajani is an Italian and yesterday he offended the European people and the Italian people!  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: No, Mr Viotti! I will not allow that either. It is not enough to use Article 21 here as a sesame-opener. This is not a point of order. (Tumult in the Hall) Who would like to raise a point of order? Mrs Agea, I would like to thank Mrs Agea for her

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, I would like to point out that the fascist regime in Italy has left... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Madam President, thank you very well I do not allow this speech either. You don't have the floor, you don't have a microphone anymore. Please sit down, otherwise I will have to call you to order. (Tumult in the Hall) Mrs Agea, please sit down. You do not have the floor. Now that there is obviously no longer a point of order that really relates to the Rules of Procedure, I am now re-offering The floor to Mr Verhofstadt.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think that Esteban Pons was fully right when he said, a few moments ago, that it is absolutely stupid from all sides to have this debate here and for us to mix this with the start of an electoral campaign which for some of us already seems to have started. But I have to tell you the first person who has to respect this is the President of the Parliament not to start his Italian campaign, because that is the problem that we are facing for the moment. For that reason (and I will finish with this) – you are chairing our plenary today – I ask you, based on our Rules of Procedure, to ask the President to take back these words; to apologise for them. And secondly, let’s start our work as plenary immediately. And that’s your task to do so, Mr President.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his I have taken note of your request. Of course, the President will become aware of everything that is happening here. But as with everything that happens here, this knowledge is not made public.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, in line with Rule 59(3), I’d like to request that the House proceed to vote on the amendments. Unfortunately, the PPE and S&D Groups have colluded in the negotiations to prevent other political groups from having a meaningful say in this package, which will hurt borrowers and give a free rein to vultures. So we are asking that a vote be taken by roll call to allow our amendments to protect European homeowners from evictions.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the text adopted in the committee has been voted for by a very broad majority. We were accused, the last time I discussed this with Mr Giegold, of producing a text that is too soft and not sufficiently strong on NPLs. Now we have the opposite accusation. The reality is that this is a very balanced text that would prevent precisely those things about which concern has been raised. So I would encourage the House to vote as the committee did and adopt it by a broad majority.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the Greens/EFA Group and with reference to Rule 191 of the Rules of Procedure, I would like to request the postponement of the votes on the following two reports. The fact is that – for many years and again in the latest resolution a few seconds ago – we have been asking for more gender equality in top EU financial posts. But the situation is: on the Executive Board of the European Central Bank (ECB) we have one woman and five men; on the General Council of the ECB we have one woman and 22 men; on the Single Resolution Board we have one woman and five men. And the same pattern is repeated in the other institutions. Therefore, the question is: how long shall women wait for a European Parliament which ensures their equal opportunities, rather than waving through one appointment after another? (Applause) Our Conference of Presidents has written two letters to the Commission and the Council, and they have received extremely evasive answers. Therefore, it is now time … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President I could easily say that in the vote we just had on the resolution, with 407 Members against and 114 for, we already decided on the issue that Sven Giegold proposed – i.e. to postpone. Why did such a broad majority decide not to postpone the vote? Because postponing the vote, in my view, is the wrong answer to the right issue, because the issue you are signalling is absolutely right.  And then the reason why we, in this resolution, have defined an action plan to increase the number of women in top financial positions, and that's the reason why we have been engaging with the Council and the Commission to have answers, letters and clear commitments for the future on our questions. But, if you look to the specific requests that Mr Giegold is asking, they are wrong, and I can explain to you why if you just give me five seconds. Why should we postpone the appointment of Mr Laviola, which has been adopted by 88% of the Members of this committee? He is qualified. He is a member of a body chaired by a woman and in all the election procedure of this body, women have been on the shortlist.

name: France JAMET
text: Mr President, in accordance with Article 108 on trade agreements and on the resumption of these negotiations with the United States, I would like to inform my colleagues that the US trade representative has indicated that such an agreement is absolutely impossible without agriculture being included in the negotiations. I wanted to tell you this solemn...  (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Jamet, I would like to thank Mrs Jamet for her work That was not a point of order. And if that is repeated, I will call you to order.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by What this regulation proposes is a step towards making the internet more in order. I feel sorry for the rapporteur, who was supposed to represent the Pirate Party in this Parliament, and in fact she turns out to be more of a corsiper at the services of a European super-state.  By inviting the European Union authorities to stimulate research, these studies will serve to justify government interference, to justify the medding of governments and the European Union on the internet. Whoever pays simply requires it. Subsidising infrastructure will give the Union an excuse to issue injunctions and bans in the interests of protecting the infrastructure it is building for its own money. Financial support for new companies will only make them dependent on power and will make long-term investments not pay off if the State continues to subsidise new ers. The power of the internet is its independence – we do not need the European Union to defend itself. So that paws down from the internet!

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, Cihan Özkan, Hüseyin Günakan, Kahraman Demirez, Mustafa Erdem, Osman Karakaya, Yusuf Karabina and many others are journalists or teachers of Turkish origin who were abducted from Kosovo, the Republic of Moldova and other countries in August and September last year. In total, last year alone, in 2018, there are 12. Obviously, all these kidnappings were done at Erdogan's behest, with the complicity of the authorities in these countries. I saw the images of teachers being brutally arrested, right in front of the school, right in front of the house, right on the street, right in the classroom. They were kidnapped and taken to the airport, boarded a plane and sent, automatically, to Turkey, without any extradition process and without any extradition request, simply kidnapping. Thank you to everyone who signed letters with me for saving these people.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because I think it is important that the European Parliament has made it clear that, in the current situation in Turkey, it is not possible to continue Turkey's negotiating and association process with the European Union. The situation of the company there and, above all, the leadership of the state is so different from the European perception of democracy and the protection of human rights that it is not possible to talk about Turkey as a country that could become a member of the European Union in some time.
