On the other hand, we need to have good relations with Turkey, it is a country that is part of nato's defence community, but it must be acknowledged that, in short, in terms of membership of the European Union, this is not realistic at the moment. And that is what the resolution contains, which is why I supported it.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by During this one part-session – although we have two monthly sessions this month to vent our increased legislative diarrhea at the end of the term – we have already managed to induce Vietnam, Russia, Iran, Guatemala, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Venezuela, Afghanistan and Nicaragua. I hope I didn't miss anything.  Now, of course, it is time for Turkey. Do you really think someone is reading this? Resolutions made some sense when they were applied exceptionally, in exceptional circumstances, rarely. When we spend ten of them a month, i don't think anybody else, apart from the members of this House, is making any impression. In addition, even the right remarks and the rightest talk in such an ideological, left-wing syfie that it simply cannot be supported. In this case, we again have social rights, workers' rights, meddled in the division of powers between the authorities in Turkey, a ban on building a nuclear power plant, the integration of the Roma for taxpayer's money and the fight against anti-gypsyism, so non possumus. I couldn't support it.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I appreciate that this report sums up a lot of ongoing issues with Turkey. Without any doubt, we are dealing with a very unpredictable and precarious neighbour. Turkey’s administration and its armies symbolise suffering and misery to those living nearby, including Christians, Kurds, Turkmens and Armenians. As a flagship of democracy, the EU should be able to have a clear position on Turkey. That is why the European Christian Political Movement, which I chair, initiated a petition to end accession talks definitively. Otherwise, we will keep the door open and communicate to minorities living under oppression in the Middle East that we do not care. But we do care and we have to tell them so. The ending of accession talks is a strong political gesture but the current state of affairs in Turkey makes it deserved. There is no time simply for suspension, as referred to in the report.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I supported the European Parliament's report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies, especially since we must not abandon the subject of employment. Despite the fact that we have economic growth, problems remain in the European labour market. These are, in particular, large differences in both employment and remuneration levels between European countries. We can also expect the possibility of a crisis or an increase in unemployment. We will face challenges such as the increase in robotics, the possible arrival of a new crisis, or the ageing of the population. That's why I think we need to think about the future. At the same time, the still high level of in-work poverty, which stands at 9.6%, is unacceptable to me. Efforts should also be made to reduce the gender pay gap.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I supported the report on the Generalised System of Preferences. I agree with the importance of this system, which is a tool to promote poverty reduction in less developed countries through international trade. I agree with the recommendation for a future revision of the current system. The area that we should focus on is the position of women in countries that receive support through the Generalised System of Preferences. I would stress the situation of women and also of human rights. Despite the fact that this system has already contributed to improving the economic position of women, many women are still subject to discrimination and working conditions are not satisfactory. Therefore, the support and emphasis on environmental protection in these countries is also an important recommendation contained in the report.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the EU is continuously improving its policies on human rights and trade agreements. Our Generalised Scheme of Preferences for Trade Tariffs sits within a broader human rights policy. It underlines the potential of GSP+ schemes to promote human rights, equality and sustainable development and the eradication of child and forced labour. The European Parliament’s report on GSP recognises the potential of the scheme and highlights the shortcomings of the GSP+ schemes and calls for improvements. This is in line with our support for the UN’s binding mechanism on human rights in trade agreements, as voted in this Parliament last October. Whilst the EU could and should do so much more to promote respect for human rights in trade agreements, this will not be made easier by a weakening of the Union. Equally, outside of the EU, the UK will be toothless in its negotiations for fair trade. And as we already know, the hard Brexiteers want trade at any price. I and millions of British citizens would... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, europeans have elected almost 37% of women to this European Parliament, and when we make appointments then the citizens of Europe will not be able to participate directly, so we have a responsibility. It is regrettable that, even in this sitting today, we have only been able to appoint three men, but before that we had a good debate on women's appointments. We again call on the European Parliament, when Member States propose names, to always put forward a man and a woman, but that is all the more we should go and include women in the nomination and, at the moment, the situation is not good. There are 11 European institutions, the two are run by a woman. It is far from the will of the people. Only 25% of women are on the main chairs in general – according to what I calculated last week. Nine of the Commissioners, but never had a woman as President of the Commission. The situation is changing very slowly, and that is why real action must be taken to break the glass ceiling and to look better at gender equality in future appointments.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In the end, I voted in favour of this resolution, although, as I emphasised in my speech in the debate on it, which concerned, I would remind you, three candidates for important positions in the economic and monetary institutions of the European Union and this so-called 'shortlist', I stressed that my Group of European Conservatives and Reformists supports the gender balance in the process of selecting these candidates. But – very importantly and as I emphasised – we would also like to see a geographical balance, so as not to favour candidates from the so-called 'old Union' at the expense of the candidates of the so-called 'new Union' from Central and Eastern Europe. I have also noticed that this process must involve the election of candidates also from the European Commission, because out of the twenty-eight Commissioners-designate, we now have nineteen men and only nine women in the European Commission, but in the end, as I say, I supported this resolution.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Parliament has adopted a joint motion for a resolution on a future EU system of sanctions for human rights violations in the world. In the resolution, we call, inter alia, for the freezing of assets and the ban on entry into the Union against any natural person or entity responsible for planning gross human rights violations, abuses and systemic corruption. We expect the new system to act as a deterrent, although I am personally not convinced of this. It is of concern that, to that end, the Member States of the Union must interpret, clarify and enforce the application of sanctions in the same consistent manner. Despite these reservations, I have decided to support this resolution.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, this week the European Parliament has welcomed many teenagers who are fighting climate change here. Welcome to this fight which tomorrow will also be saying loud and clear tomorrow: fighting climate change across Europe. I join in this fight for clean air, for a clean land. I join in this struggle for a country that can divide with full protection of the environment. And I also want to bring a very important problem of my country, Galicia: the problem of fires, fires that also affect the air, and bring the problem of eucalyptus. The eucalyptus medra, the Government favors its planting and forest plans are created that go against the environment. We will talk about this tomorrow in Santiago de Compostela, and we will also talk about this next week at a conference we will organise on water in the European Parliament.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, hear the youth of the world and Europe, which has become our saving hope when everything worsens for the climate. Hear this conscious youth that intimates the adults and the powerful to act now for the climate, for species, for a possible future on Earth. This youth tells us that it is no longer urgent to wait, but that there is an urgent need to act and change everything from top to bottom. What is happening is historic! It is the youth that guides us and shows us the way, they do not want to be drawn into this blind march, led by the blind and which rushes us all towards a precipice. This youth has understood everything. The time for climate justice has come. One, two, three degrees, she says, is a crime against humanity.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, the student strike denounces how the European Union does not live up to the challenge posed by climate change. Your message is clear. We must assume that we are facing a climate emergency and that a drastic reduction in greenhouse emissions is needed.  With our vote we want to show our support for the youth mobilizing in defence of the existence of a dignified future and also denounce the hypocrisy and inaction of the European Union in the face of the challenge of climate change. We need courageous governments and institutions to end environmentally squeezing and social rights-squeezing policies. We can't go on like we have been here before. We need to accelerate the energy transition and the change of economic and social system, because our lives and our planet are worth more than their benefits and nothing can justify being robbed of the future.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, the Commission has presented two possible roadmaps on how we can achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 at the latest, but that goal means that we must tighten up the targets as early as 2030. Today, again, Parliament has voted in favour of the target of setting emission reductions at 55% in 2030, a 55% cut from 90% in 2030. This objective is also supported by several Member States, and it is very much to be hoped that my own country, Finland, when it takes over as President of the EU next July, will also be able to rally a majority on the Council side behind us acting quickly. The new Commission must also immediately take steps to make concrete proposals to achieve this objective. Schoolchildren are also going on climate strike in Finland this coming Friday because they want us adult decision-makers to act.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In the resolution of our Group of European Conservatives and Reformists, we note that the European Union is responsible for less than 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions and that the Union cannot itself achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement without the participation of the world's largest economies.  The joint resolution voted does not refer to the use of the Union's own raw materials and, consequently, to ensure the Community's energy security by, for example, supporting clean coal technologies and, more specifically, gasifying coal aimed at obtaining hydrogen as a clean energy carrier. I therefore voted against this joint resolution.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A zero-emission economy is a political pipe dream. There is no such thing, there was and probably will not be for a long time yet. We don't have that technology, and no matter how much you don't bang your fist on the table here, it won't change. You can nod your finger in your shoe, you can write everything – the paper is patient, but it will not change the facts. We can write that the Earth from tomorrow will spin the other way, but it will not. And there will also be no such technology that will allow us not to emit greenhouse gases in the foreseeable future. The only effect of setting unrealistic goals is that nothing is achieved. The only effect will be to insemnate the European economy, which is traditional for socialists, without making any progress in the field of climate. In addition, you are writing about a stable and predictable energy policy framework. In the year since I have been in this Parliament, we have already voted on more than a dozen climate policy changes. The name is not stable and unpredictable, no one can invest, feeling safe that parliament will not change its current policy tomorrow.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, climate change is a global phenomenon that knows no borders. We in Europe have a huge responsibility to the rest of the world, particularly those living in fragile countries. We also have a huge responsibility for the world that we bequeath to future generations. I’ve been supporting the young people, inspired by Greta Thunberg, who are participating in the Friday school strikes, demanding urgent action to ensure that life on earth in all its diversity will continue. But are we listening? As a co-founder of the European Parliament’s Child Rights Intergroup, it is disappointing to see conservative forces ignore and belittle these concerned youth, denying them opportunities to participate in our policy-making. I particularly want to draw attention to an amazing youth group in my constituency in a school in Accrington, called the Eco Group, who came to the European Parliament to present their ideas about the environment. They are the leaders of the future.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the joint resolution on climate change because I do not want us to reach a point of no return, to a point where successive environmental disasters will prevent our stay on planet Earth.  The political class must show unity on the issue and cannot devalue the signs that are too evident, such as the worsening of extreme climate episodes and global warming.  Resource optimisation is essential to avoid over-exploitation and, to do so, we need a collaborative effort between the agriculture and industry sectors, in line with the most conscientious and responsible consumers.  With scientific and technological advances we already have the ability to reproduce clean energy and use renewable sources. Therefore, it makes no sense to perpetuate the error of using fossil fuels. But for this transition, we need a broad commitment and a political and executive consensus at the various levels of governance: European, national and local. We must finance the transition to an ecological and sustainable economy in a more definitive and ambitious way, without losing ourselves in cosmetic measures and in false improvements brought about by the greed of some sectors of the business. Protecting the environment is protecting humanity's constructive future. I just hope it's not too late.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, are the leaders of the European Union more afraid of Mr Donald Trump's chin-kicking and angry tweets than the anger of the peoples of Europe? That is the question we have when we see that the Commission has rushed to negotiate a trade agreement with the United States again. And what is the United States doing? They increase their tariffs, they prohibit us from trading with Iran, they do not respect the Paris agreement. What is the Commission's response to the European Union? Resuscitate the TAFTA. It is the return of the zombie TAFTA, with the same concerns, the same uncertainties about agriculture, about regulatory cooperation, about the importation of shale gas... In short, these are always the same problems and we are being offered a solution that the people have rejected overwhelmingly. We've thrown the TAFTA out the door, we're trying to get it in through the window. We oppose this attempt and these harmful policies!

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Mr President, since the protests began in Nicaragua, there have been more than seventy-six deaths, eight hundred people injured and hundreds of detainees.  We condemn violence against popular movements and call for an independent investigation for those responsible to be held accountable in court for severe human rights violations.  We support a dialogue that includes all voices and allows a dialogued exit to this conflict, a solution that goes through the freedom of all political prisoners, the disarmament of paramilitary gangs and ensuring the most basic social and political freedoms, such as demonstration, assembly, protest, participation and the right to information.  As Nicaraguan history has shown us, the exercise of protest must serve to advance the political and social transformations of the country. The future of Nicaragua, in short, must be decided by Nicaraguans with full autonomy and freedom, free from violence and repression and ensuring the return of all exiles.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, a key principle of the SDGs is that they are universal and that all countries must do their bit, at home as well as abroad, to meet the targets, but I fear that we are failing. I brought with me a shopping list today. Tinned veg, tinned fruit, long-life milk, fruit juice and pasta sauce. That’s the current list of the top five items needed at the Luton Food Bank. The UKSSD Measuring Up report looked at the zero-hunger goal with a green, amber and red scoring system. Britain didn’t score green for a single target. It is frankly shocking that this government is content to watch one in five children in Britain live in homes that are severely food insecure, making it the worst for child hunger in all of Europe. We have had four years to think about how to address the sustainable development goals. Now it is time to act.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are a commitment to transform our world so that future generations can live in harmony and peace in a much more equal world without poverty and with respect for the environment. All 17 goals identify urgent matters that must be addressed and I applaud the European Parliament’s work to stress the legitimacy of the SDGs as a standard for our economies. Economic and sustainable development must go hand in hand and growth cannot be understood simply in terms of GDP. In particular, with regard to Goal 4, quality education, I must condemn the damage that austerity has inflicted on our education services. Quality education is the best investment a government can make and yet education is one of the sectors worst affected by austerity measures. The SDGs are now included in the EU countries’ broader economic strategies. However, the UK’s departure from the EU allows the Conservative government to ignore current EU economic policy, which calls for substantial investment in public services including education.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on John Flack's oral question to the Commission on rules on animal welfare in aquaculture, Fabio Massimo Castaldo, Arne Gericke, Fredrick Federley, Ivo Vajgl, Karin Kadenbach, Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner, Julie Ward, Marco Zullo, Eleonora Evi, Michéle Rivasi, Stelios Kouloglou, Sven Giegold, Bart Staes, Keith Taylor, Michela Giuffrida, Paul Brannen, Pavel Poc, David Martin, Stefan Eck, Sirpa Pietikäinen, Jacqueline Foster, Tilly Metz, Davor 'krlec, Georgi Pirinski, Tonino Picula, Ji' Pospil, Tunne Kelam, Zdzis-aw Krasnod'bski, Kosma Z'otowski, Isabella De Monte, Anja Hazekamp, Kostas Chrys Klaus Buchner, Pascal Durand, Younous Omarjee, Jill Evans, Guillaume Balas, Dominique Bilde (O-000001/2019 - B8-0015/2019) - (2019/2616(RSP)).

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, recent scientific studies show us that fish are sentient animals: they have a complex nature and a rich sensory world and can experience emotions, but not only that, they also have important cognitive abilities. Unfortunately, however, perhaps precisely because of their complexity and mysteriousness, fish have always been underestimated, even often ignored and excluded from the protection guaranteed to other categories of animals.  Fish are also the most exploited and widely used type of animal. To give an idea of the phenomenon, it is estimated that 111 billion fish are caught and 1.7 billion fish are reared in aquaculture. These figures relate only to the European Union. Personally, I find it almost difficult to assimilate and rationalise the size of these figures. In the light of all this, we have a strong responsibility towards them, the same responsibility that we have towards other animals.  However, the legislation on fish welfare is minimal, and we are a long way from implementing the necessary measures to ensure compliance with international and European animal welfare standards. This is confirmed by efsa's many opinions (scientific advice that our Agency has drawn up), the repeated evidence of the inadequacy of the implementation of Regulation (EC) No 1/2005 on the transport of live animals and Regulation (EC) No 1099/2009 on the protection of animals during slaughter, and also a study by the European Commission itself carried out last year.  In view of the above, the Commission's non-action can no longer be justified. We need objective, science-based standards, we need high European standards. The possibility of setting minimum requirements through voluntary measures at Member State level and on the initiative of the industry itself has so far led to very little progress, and what little has been done at times is also disappointing.  On the basis of these considerations, we therefore call on the European Commission to introduce uniform standards on the animal welfare of fish and to ensure that European regulations are actually complied with and implemented.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, fish are sentient beings indeed. It is true that they are quite different from other farm species, but they are also able to suffer and feel pain. That is our starting point for this discussion. I understand that there is a growing concern for the welfare of farmed fish in the European Union. In recent years, to meet an increasing consumer demand, fish farming has intensified for some species in Europe. As the production process is intensified, it has the potential to generate new issues relating to animal welfare, notwithstanding the fact that the public also wants healthy and ethically-produced food.  In this context, you wonder why the Commission has not yet proposed specific pieces of legislation on the welfare of farmed fish. Firstly, I should clarify that the European Union animal welfare legislation already covers farmed fish at different stages of production — farming, transport and slaughter.  Secondly, I want to assure you that the Commission takes the welfare of farmed fish seriously. Let me outline some of the steps we have taken, particularly under the current Commission’s mandate to promote farmed fish welfare. Based on the 2012 EU strategy for the protection and welfare of animals, the Commission mandated a comprehensive study on the welfare of fish during transport and at the time of slaughter. The study was published in November 2017 and led to today’s oral question.  The study concluded that in the countries analysed, the transport of fish was in line with the international standards of the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), and as you know, the OIE is the international standard-setting organisation for animal welfare. The study also acknowledged that there was room for improvement when it comes to the slaughter of certain fish species.  In March 2018, based on this study, the Commission adopted a report on the possibility of introducing certain requirements regarding the protection of fish at the time of killing. The 2018 report concludes that, at this stage, it is not appropriate to propose specific requirements on the welfare of fish at the time of killing. The report indeed considers that improving the welfare of farmed fish could be more easily achieved by voluntary measures.  This conclusion is reached on the basis of the consideration that in recent years the industry has introduced improvements in this regard. We are moving in the right direction. In particular, I would like to highlight a number of important points which we should keep in mind when debating the issue. Firstly, EU aquaculture is relatively new compared to other animal products and systems. Technology to improve the welfare of farmed fish is still developing.  Secondly, the sector is a very diverse. The main farmed species — salmon, trout, carp, sea bass and sea bream — are biologically very different. Each species requires important effort in research and development.  Thirdly, furthermore the sector differs in size and geographical coverage, with a variety of practices across Member States. In this context, having a harmonised approach might be more complex than it appears. In light of these considerations, I think that Member States might be more suited to developing good practices in their national context. Nevertheless, the Commission continues to work on the welfare of farmed fish. Allow me to give you some practical examples of these efforts.  In 2018, the issue of fish welfare was put on the agenda of the two meetings of the EU animal welfare platform, which gather all key EU stakeholders related to animal welfare. In November 2018, the European Court of Auditors published a special report on animal welfare. They recommend in particular performing an evaluation of the strategy. Later this year, the Commission will launch an evaluation of the strategy.  I can assure you that the issue of farm fish will be part of the evaluation. In the meantime, the Commission will continue to monitor the situation and promote dialogue between stakeholders on this issue.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Commissioner, I also co-signed this oral question on the state of aquaculture and fish conservation. I must say, I am not very satisfied with your answer. She was very general and alibistic. I think that practice is beginning to show that we lack some legal regulation for the treatment of fish as living creatures. A similar debate took place here a few weeks ago on the transport of animals around Europe. A similar issue is likely to be addressed in the autumn of this year, when a citizens' initiative will collect a million signatures for the Commission to start addressing the issue of cage farming in Europe. In other words, unfortunately, this Commission has not done much for the status and protection of animals, whether mammals or fish. I will hope that the Commission, which will come up after the next elections, will pay more attention to this subject, because animals are living beings and we should respect this when transporting, loading and killing them, and we should treat them humanely. So the answer was general, I hope next time will be better.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the morality of human beings is judged on how they treat animals. It is disappointing that, in the European Union, we still do not have a mechanism to protect fish welfare in a coherent way throughout all the Member States. At the same time, we have good practices that may serve the Commission’s efforts in identifying improvements. Europe is still a place where numerous compromising aquaculture practices take place – handling, transport, genetic manipulation, predation, stress provocation and inhuman slaughter. At the same time, I believe that EU consumers have the right to be guaranteed that the fish reaching their tables is the product of high-quality aquaculture. I sincerely hope that the Commission is going to close the knowledge gaps related to fish welfare, organise a consultation with stakeholders and develop a reliable road map. In the light of developing techniques of fish breeding, regulations adopted in 2005 and 2009 can no longer guarantee a high level of fish welfare, and I join the signatories of this oral question in asking for EU-wide legislative requirements in aquaculture. Guaranteeing fish welfare implies certain challenges and requires flexibility. Some practices that result in positive welfare for one type of fish may negatively affect other species. That is why we cannot expect to improve welfare for aquaculture species with prescriptive standards. We must apply different criteria to small farmers and to huge aquaculture companies. For example, small producers observe fish better and are much more attentive to signs of stress. Negligence towards stress of fish can lead to outbreaks of disease and serious losses. Per capita, the yearly consumption of fish in Europe is 27 kg, and this predicted to increase. Over the past decade, aquaculture has become the fastest-growing food production sector in the world, and we must take that into account.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. Chairman, dear Mr. Commissioner, and Croatia is one of those countries that has long experience in fish farming, in aquaculture. For decades it has been done in Croatia and in the region where I was, in Istria, there are sea bass farms, there are shellfish farms and I know well what all companies do to really show that they care about the welfare of fish, about the welfare of the animals they breed. Namely, it should be said that there is no doubt that the farms will be places from where we will increasingly get fish on our table. There will be fewer and fewer fish fish, more and more fish from the farm, and partly we are to blame because we have plastic seas around us, plastic oceans around us and it is obvious that we will have to make such breeding grounds where we will really be able to breed these squat creatures, and fish that we all love, in a way that is appropriate to today's weather. That is why I believe that all these efforts we want to make here with this issue, to warn about breeding, slaughter, transport and all those elements that make up the life of fish, I think it is very important that the Commission really creates a single system, a single law that will then allow the whole of the European Union, and also those who cooperate with us to breed fish in the way that we think it should be.

name: Tilly METZ
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the biggest challenge in this regard is neither the fish nor the cruel practices inflicted on them. Indeed, there are already solutions. The challenge is to raise awareness of parliament, the policy-makers, but also all those who are listening to me at the moment, because it is a question of rediscovering fish, of seeing them in their complexity, which has long been denied. Today, we know that fish are also sensitive to pain, connect with each other and work together to protect themselves and feed. But in aquaculture, they are treated by the millions as objects. They are crammed into poor quality water, they contract diseases and are infected with parasites, they lack oxygen, they are treated with drugs and hormones, they are stressed and manipulated. In these confined spaces, they injure themselves and assault each other. These prisons do not allow them to behave normally. On the day of their death, they are brutally removed from the water, they suffocate, their stomachs are opened, while their hearts are still beating. These sensitive and much more complex beings than we imagined, when are we going to treat them more dignifiedly? I urge the Commission to propose new texts that take into account the cruel realities of the current situation in aquaculture and the discoveries of scientists about these fantastic beings, fish.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Although up to 1.7 billion fish are slaughtered in aquafarms in the EU every year, there is no proper legislation to protect these animals. Fish are still cruelly slaughtered without sufficient or no anaesthetic. In the brains of most non-empathetic politicians in this House, in the Commission and in the Council, they have been and are regarded as a senseless and low way of life.  Apparently, all the findings of biology have passed without a trace on the organ of these ladies and gentlemen. In the light of my experience, I have little hope that there is any political will at all for effective legislation. When it comes to animals, the Commission is blind and deaf. But animal cruelty is a criminal offence in all Member States, at least on paper. It is therefore criminal, as the Commission, which is obviously going on the aisle of the fishing industry, is still treating this species to this day. I appeal to you to finally turn on the brain and heart, if any, and to make a push so that fish at least have minimum standards to protect them.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am taking the floor again this time on behalf of my political group and the 5-star Movement. I am reporting the views of European citizens, because 79 % of citizens want fish to be better protected than they are at present and for them to be given at least the level of protection that we already guarantee to other animals that many people feed on. Furthermore, nine out of ten people believe that culling in the absence of pain is an essential aspect of fish welfare, and so these seem to me to be unequivocal data that the Commission can no longer ignore.  Secondly, there are other things that should not be ignored: there are public health considerations. Animals that are kept unsatisfactory in overcrowded facilities are stressed animals, which get sick more easily, and all this leads to greater use of chemicals, antibiotics, to deal with and contain outbreaks of diseases.  Thirdly, the lack of animal welfare standards also has several environmental consequences. I am thinking, for example, of algal blooms, the creation of so-called dead zones, real dead areas near aquaculture sites, with possible effects on natural fish resources and biodiversity. I mean, it's time to take action. I believe that the European Commission should do more. The answer given to us by the Commissioner is unsatisfactory. There are many things that can be done, as well as, of course, more stringent standards and the application of existing ones. , for example, also a reference centre for animal and fish welfare.  In conclusion, I can only be very dissatisfied and saddened by the fact that this very House has decided not to even make a political resolution to put in black and white what we are telling each other today.

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, thank you for speaking. At the initiative of my party, the netherlands started the creation of an animal police in the Netherlands in 2010. The animal police act against people who neglect and abuse animals, and also try to prevent animal cruelty. Penalties for animal cruelty, poaching and similar offences and crimes have also increased in recent years. In addition, a special telephone number, called "1 4 4", has been opened to report animal cruelty. The people behind this hotline ensure that the report reaches the right authority. In total, several hundred officers are active in combating animal cruelty. After a few years, it has been shown that the number of reports of animal cruelty has increased, and that more and more offenders are being dealt with. In short, a good thing. The authors of the questions to the European Commission therefore rightly indicate that there are examples of effective animal welfare policy in several Member States. As I have just said, the Netherlands is on the right track in this respect. Of course, improvements are always possible. But the basics are. It does not happen very often, but I have to pay tribute to the Commission here. It seems that we have finally seen the light and the realisation that not everything has to be arranged in Brussels or here in Strasbourg. And that, Mr President, is exactly how it should go. The Dutch voter determines what the policy on animal welfare should be. It is a competence of the national parliaments and the European Union should not interfere in this at all. National parliaments are very capable of regulating this themselves. Of course, countries can share excellent, good ideas and practices among themselves. They don't need the EU for that. Respect the sovereignty of the Member States. Let countries decide for themselves what measures they want to introduce or do not. Leave it to the people themselves, self-regulation and the trade associations.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, in my country, fish is more than a food, it is a national symbol. So I am very concerned about this issue because one of the fundamental problems is that Europe has to decide between which fishing models, whether it is sustainable fishing or intensive or extensive aquaculture. I am in favour of extensive aquaculture because facilities in intensive aquaculture often do not meet adequate conditions to have healthy fish. Due to productivity, intensive aquaculture models that use antibiotics and hormones that stress fish are promoted. Fish slaughter is quickly done to obtain benefits and these benefits are often concentrated in a few hands, unlike extensive aquaculture, Commissioner, which is shellfish harvesting or small-scale aquaculture facilities, which also give a lot of work. Between the two models, I also believe that the Commission should, in future European funds, in the future European Maritime Fisheries Fund, fight for the animal welfare of fish, but also protect another model of extensive aquaculture alternative to this stressful model, to this model that uses antibiotics, to this model that makes this type of fish slaughter and that causes questions like these.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – Mr President, fish have awareness and feeling. They can suffer pain, and experience anxiety and stress. And suffering, they do so in The European Aquaculture, which is of course nothing but intensive fish farming. European fish farms slaughter more than one and a half billion fish a year. Three trillion more fish die at sea. And the way is gruesome. Almost all fish are slaughtered unsedated and have a long, long death struggle. Cod can stay conscious for hours on ice or in the air. Eels let's cremate in salt baths. The Commission would come forward with proposals to put an end to this as early as 2014. That didn't happen. There were some reports in which you say that the welfare of fish in Europe is in bad ly bad. However, that is the end of it. When can we expect concrete action? These animals have nothing to do with your reports and your evaluations. That is also why I believe that European agricultural and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, is dóigh liom gur fiú an cheist seo a phlé. Agus tugaim moladh do na Feisirí Flack agus Evi as ucht an cheist a chur, agus mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir, bunaithe ar thaighde agus staidéar atá déanta acu le cúig bliana anuas. Agus is dócha go raibh baint ag mo chomhghleacaí Éireannach thíos ansin, an tréadlia Kilgallen, leis an taighde sin.  Gan dabht ar bith, tá éileamh níos mó, bliain i ndiaidh bliana, ar éisc agus níl siad ar fáil go fiáin. Dá bhrí sin, tá na feirmeacha éisc ag fás gach uile bhliain agus is saghas tionscadal nua é, mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid a bheith an-chúramach go mbeidh an caighdeán is airde in sna feirmeacha sin. Níl an dara rogha againn, agus freisin, mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir, cúramach freisin nuair a bhíonn siad ag taisteal nó á n—iompar ó fheirmeacha go monarchana, agus go háirithe agus iad á gcur chun báis, go ndéanfar é gan fulaingt rómhór orthu.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, let us congratulate my colleague on the very important issue raised. He gives us a lot of answers. In the Hall of the European Parliament we debate, discuss feelings, emotions, injury to fish. And then we ask ourselves why there is also so much skepticism in some of the citizens of the European Union. When they observe this debate, it may be extremely interesting and important for them to learn exactly what the emotions of fish are at a time. And then they ask themselves why they pay taxes and with their taxes what we do in this room – we deal with feelings, emotions of fish. It must be useful. I would focus more on the interests, the rights, the expectations of our fellow citizens to work for their well-being and their way of life, and not so much to be interested in emotions of fish.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened with great interest to this discussion and I am grateful for your valuable insights. It is clear that the welfare of farm fish presents many challenges and I am thankful we had the opportunity to discuss this issue. So where do we go from here?  Firstly, we need to develop scientific knowledge to better understand the needs of the different species at various stages of production. Secondly, we need to take into account the variety of the production systems in the European Union, which range from big industrial farms to small or medium sized companies.Thirdly, we need to engage with the industry, NGOs and the scientific community, in a constructive dialogue.  The goal here is to find sustainable and coherent solutions to the issues facing EU aquaculture today, including those relating to the environment, animal health, the use of antibiotics and animal welfare.  I agree wholeheartedly that animal welfare is one issue that has to be integrated into the long-term strategy of the EU aquaculture sector. Next year we should have the results of the evaluation of the EU animal welfare strategy. This will outline the starting point of future initiatives on animal welfare, including for farmed fish.  Let me finish by assuring you that the Commission will maintain a high interest in the welfare of fish and will persist in encouraging stakeholders to work together for further improvements.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the fundamental rights of people of African descent by Claude Moraes on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000022/2019 - B8-0016/2019) - (2018/2899(RSP)).

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are opening this debate on the situation of European citizens of African origin by taking this opportunity to shine a spotlight on the specific form of social exclusion they face. In this presentation, it is my duty to explain to the Presidency of this House, to the members of the Commission, who are the addressees of the question, to the Members present and to the citizens, the whole meaning of the question itself and the way in which the subject should be included in our future parliamentary work. In this respect, Mr President, I would like to stress the good climate that prevailed in the LIBE Committee when it came to agreeing on the final version of the resolution to be adopted in plenary at the next part-session. Thanks to the effective and competent mediation of Claude Moraes, we broadly supported the content of the resolution, with the convincing participation, in particular, of the ALDE, GUE, Verts/ALE and PPE Groups. Of course, there was no shortage of controversy. The official recognition of the specific history of afro-descendants, the possibility of establishing reparations, the issue of public apology, but also the issue of the return of artistic goods to African countries, once plundered by the colonising European nations, and the issue of the declassification of the colonial archives deserve the establishment of a european Commission unit that deals specifically with these issues and the promotion of full citizenship of African-descendant Europeans. These were, broadly, the issues that animated our debate in committee, and we can be quite satisfied with the final version of the resolution, which is the result of serious and competent mediation. We now need to return for a moment to the general importance of this issue, in order to reaffirm some of the principles that led us to its treatment. The equal social integration of European citizens of African descent must, in my view, be seen in the context of the need to respect fundamental human rights. It is a question, on the whole, of guaranteeing the bearers of diversity the integrity of human dignity of which they are indisputable holders. These statements, which start from the elementary levels of our political reflection, are motivated by the fact that in today's Europe, despite centuries of theorization of rationality and social evolution, there are still disvalues, which undermine the lives of Afro-descendants. It is often said in half, because this seems unthinkable: yet, a specific research by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights has given us evidence of the existence, within European society, of recursive phenomena of anti-black racism. Moreover, in several Member States, daily news is often dominated by incidents of racism and xenophobia, which affect African-descendants of Europe indifferently and tend to push them to the margins of society. The extent of the phenomenon is such that no social sector can be considered immune. The rights to housing, the right to access decent work and the right to education are particularly violated. In some European countries, we have even seen the attempted return of apartheid, with the discriminatory exclusion of Afro-descendant children from school canteens, as well as the attempt to establish separate classes for them. When I was reporting on the disputes in the Committee on Civil Rights, Human Rights, Common Security and Consumer Policy, I referred to the issue of historical relations between European countries, which are now members of the Union, and African countries, the last place of origin of African-Europeans. This historical relationship has seen the post-medieval explorations, the black slave trade, colonisation, the total economic exploitation of Africa and the barely veiled forms of neo-colonialism that prevail in our time. Often, within this House, as well as within our societies, the issue of migration, an essential component of globalisation, has electrified our debates, also soothing our differences of opinion. I believe that the question of the full citizenship of black Europeans, African-descendants, must be included in this set of subjects, so that we can understand their depth, but also in order to remedy them. Often, even among us, I have seen some of our colleagues be surprised to hear me say that there is racism in Europe, considering it an almost exclusively American phenomenon. Yet, in the cradle of humanist culture, not only are racist and xenophobic acts teeming, but in some contexts, they become part of a theory of government... (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs for drawing attention to this matter. The Commission is concerned about the high rates of discrimination and the manifestations of hatred reported to be seriously affecting people of African descent and black people in Europe, as recently shown by Fundamental Rights Agency research. Preventing and fighting afrophobia and other forms of racism are fully embedded in the Commission’s policies against discrimination and racism, which remain a clear priority for us. EU action in this area comprises a variety of measures and tools, including the continuing monitoring of the transposition and implementation of relevant EU legislation and, in particular, the Race Equality Directive and the Framework Decision on combating racism. In the past years, we have been working hard to provide national authorities with guidance on how to ensure the effective implementation of legislation. We have focused on data on equality and hate crime, victim support and improving investigation into, and the prosecution of, hate speech and hate crime. Last November, we published a new guidance note on the practical application of the EU Framework Decision on combating racism, which will serve as a useful tool to prompt and assist national law-enforcement and judicial authorities in better enforcing national legislation on hate crime and hate speech on the ground. Flagship policy initiatives, such as a code of conduct on countering illegal hate speech online, and the work on diversity chapters, are also providing a key contribution to concrete progress on the ground. All these horizontal initiatives play a key role in terms of preventing and countering afrophobia and anti-black racism. But, indeed, the recognition of afrophobia and anti-black racism as a specific form of racism is important. Following thematic discussion in the EU High Level Group on combating racism and other forms of intolerance, we published last November a policy paper which provides an overview of the main issues raised by stakeholders on the specific barriers, prejudices and obstacles facing people of African descent and black people across Europe. On this basis, targeted measures are identified, in order effectively to address discrimination, exclusion and intolerance directed against those communities. We hope this policy paper can be a useful tool both for policymakers at EU and national level and for NGOs and other stakeholders. I look forward to this debate and to the ideas of the European Parliament, which will be reflected in the resolution.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, in the context of combating institutional, personal and internalised racism, the UN has decreed the period from 2015 to 2024 as the international decade of Afrodescendants.  Despite this proclamation, the truth is that in the Member States of the European Union Afrodescendants remain racially, socially and legally discriminated against, more vulnerable to unemployment and, because of their political under-representation in the European institutions, prevented from contributing to the elimination of these forms of discrimination to which they are targeted.  This sad panorama is a shame that occurs a little throughout Europe, including in my country, where Afrodescendants are particularly vulnerable socially and economically and where unfortunately reports of police violence based on racial discrimination persist, where countless Portuguese Afrodescendants continue to be treated as immigrants and immigrant Afrodescendants see the right to nationality restricted to them and their inherent rights to them being denied by institutional racism that persists in maintaining themselves in the 21st century. It is therefore urgent to create a European Union framework for national strategies for the inclusion and social integration of Afrodescendants that includes promoting political empowerment, combating Afrophobia and hate crimes.  In the 21st century, we cannot remain impassive to witness discriminatory treatment among citizens, whether on the basis of colour, religion or sexual choices. Europe is, and should remain, an area of freedom, solidarity and equal opportunities for all and non-discrimination in access to employment, wages and even access to health care.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to point out from here that it is the sole task of the institution to remember that racism is prohibited. I'm leaving here to talk about a concept that very often runs through our society. This is the presumption of guilt, so this is the horrible name of a fact that spreads in a pandemic way in our European society, finding in the existence of stereotypes the reasons for its maintenance. Because of the presumption of guilt, many Afro-descendant European citizens are exposed to harassment and ill-treatment. Sometimes it is difficult to talk about it firsthand, for those who suffer from racism and xenophobia. It is difficult to talk about this because, precisely because of the presumption of guilt, one is immediately accused of victimism and simulation. Yet, Mr President, there is not a single African-descended European who cannot recognise the fact that he has often felt excluded, or simply targeted, because of the evidence of his own skin difference. Of course, it may also be a collective illusion, but it selectively affects and exposes black Europeans to discriminatory profiling by the police as well; to suffer institutional racism, as we have heard; to be refused their application for rental homes, without anyone having previously examined the practice. To tell you the depth of the matter, think that often, during routine police checks, it happens that the African-descending European citizen, holder of a regular identity card that bears the clear mention of his citizenship, hears the unexpected question: "Where is the residence permit?". There are many of these episodes.  However, I must thank this Parliament for the avant-garde regulation we have against verbal racism of elected representatives. This is good practice, which must be disseminated throughout Europe and throughout the world, to protect the humanity of all men and women.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, the ideology prevailing in the European Union is cultural Marxism, which differs from classical Marxism in that, in place of old notions of exploitation, it introduced the concept of discrimination and tracks down other discriminated groups, but above all uses it because stigmatising society without interruption as a discriminatory structure, showing "discriminates against those who are, those still others" actually causes social antagonism that undermines each other. We really shouldn't go down that path with that.  Setting up a thought police, establishing special laws – all this is not the way to build a solidarity society. If anyone in our countries is harmed, then there should be a strong, consistently enforced law protecting every person who has been harmed.  The tool for building solidarity is simply education, the Christian culture in which we were raised, and certainly not the police of thought, which will only escalate further social conflicts.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. Chairman, we all know that we live at a time when populism is growing, when hatred is growing, when the placement of falsehoods is a completely natural thing, when we have a strong growth in nationalism, when we have relationships where homophobia is coming to light right now, afrophobia is coming to light. And look, our President of the European Parliament at this time relativises what Mussolini did, who passed racist laws. So we live in a time when we really need to be concerned about the society we're creating. Do we really want a society where people will hate each other because they belong to different faiths, nations or are they different skin colours (as in this case a question was asked of colleague Kyenga in a great way)?  I want to believe, I want to be naïve, I want to be a magician as well, but I want to believe that this planet of ours has a chance. He has a chance in what made me fight to get into this European Parliament: in European values. In what means mutual tolerance, mutual understanding and mutual desire for a culture of living.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, for the first time, we have a debate in this Chamber on Afrophobia, a racism based mainly on skin colour. Afro-descendants are immigrants, descendants of immigrants but also Europeans, some, for several generations, like our fellow ultramarine. There is an unthinkable, a specific racism towards black people, linked to the history of the European continent, a refusal to confront our history and its violence vis-à-vis Africa, through slavery, human trafficking, colonialism and neocolonialism. It is even found in some political discourses, especially with regard to sub-Saharan migrants. So, yes, we must talk about this history without taboo, unravel prejudices, recognize facts and what must be called "crimes against humanity", understand the specifics of this racism to prevent it from being perpetuated, including in our institutions, to educate, and condemn discrimination and violence, including police. We must accept otherness and make article 1 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights live and say, with Aimé Césaire, there is an essential fact, we are black and that counts.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I also want to subscribe to this question, which has been put to the Commission for answer. As my colleagues have already said, this is an extremely important issue – the fight against racism, xenophobia, the protection of our Citizens of the European Union, who have their ancestors from Africa and are often discriminated against because of their skin colour. It's an extremely important topic. It is a pity that it is discussed in this way here on Thursday at the end of the plenary session. But it is also a good challenge for the next European Commission and the next European Parliament to pay much more attention to this issue. It is clear to me that this Commission, although the Commissioner has read some activities here, may not do much work on this important subject, but it is important that the next Commission takes for its tougher fight against racism and xenophobia and greater efforts to integrate into European societies those of our fellow citizens who, for some reason, are vulnerable and are simply discriminated against or are affected by racism.  It is very important that we can admit this, that we can say that there is racism in European communitiesism, that the descendants of Africans, our African fellow citizens, are often discriminated against, and that not only nation states but also the European Commission need to pay attention to this both institutionally, this has been talked about here, and above all financially. This is the question for the Financial Policy of the European Union in the next planning period.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, the issue of the fundamental rights of the people of Africa in Europe is interesting. That must be a very important question. It concerns topics that need to be discussed a lot. However, for me, as a representative of the Bulgarian nation in the European Parliament, the rights and legitimate interests of Bulgarian citizens, for example, 500 thousand of them, who will be forced to migrate to Western Europe if the Mobility package or the Macron package happens, are very important and very visible. So I do not object to leftists all over Europe and in this European Parliament finding problems and fighting them. We live in free societies. Everyone has the right to fight their political battles. But at the end of the day, the questions of the citizens of the African countries should be questions of the African countries. We, the representatives of European countries, must take care of the rights and legitimate interests of our citizens.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think this is a very important topic and I’m delighted to see it being highlighted here today. As people become more and more sophisticated and well-off across Europe, are they becoming more tolerant? It’s a good question. It’s not easy to answer it. There’s plenty of evidence to suggest that that’s not the case, and therefore it’s fundamental that the European Parliament would be aware of these issues to try and get fairness and equality across Europe for everybody, and particularly for people of African descent. They should have the same opportunity to get employment. They shouldn’t be subjected to hate speech or hate crime, and that should apply in every walk of life. I’ve seen in recent times, especially in sports, where even people of African descent and others, are abused simply because of their race. We have to stop this and I think the European Parliament and the European institutions can play a leading role because in this day and age we have to have equality for everybody, male and female, African and non-African alike. That is what we have to aspire to in the next Parliament.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, unfortunately, racism is still a reality in Europe with widespread discrimination against people of African descent. Black women and LGBTIQ+ people face a particularly bleak situation as they find themselves at the intersection of discrimination based on race and gender. Access to employment, housing, education and other opportunities remains much more difficult for people of African descent. This is made worse when it comes, for instance, to trans women of colour who are also the target of unparalleled levels of violence.  Racism in Europe is rooted in centuries of colonisation and the bullying of African countries by the West. We need to address these historical trends and accept that they are still at play today, as we have seen in this very debate. However, as the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination approaches, I know that thousands of anti-racist activists will march on the streets, calling for a world against racism. It’s time to stop ignoring the daily reality of life for Europeans of African descent and Mr Dzhambazki needs to understand that we all are from the same DNA.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I came to this debate out of curiosity to listen to what you mean here, and frankly at the end I still don't know. All but two of the previous previous ers spoke the same generalities. I do not know where you get the data from, that this is an ever-growing problem. I wanted to ask this question to Mr Jakovčiciovi, but he left anyway, so he will not answer me. Where does the data come from that this problem is growing? What observations justify such a belief that we have a growing problem with racism, homophobia – as he called it. I think we have a problem with homolification, if any, with such praise of deviance in this Parliament, not with homophobia. So what's the problem? Where do you have this data? Where are these specifics? On what basis do you bother with such strange discussions at all? It seems to me that this is a completely marginal problem, and perhaps only in connection with the upcoming elections do you want to win some more votes from people who are interested in it, but I see no reason for us to do so. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Blue card question. My question is very brief. I would like him to state here that black people of African origin are not part of Europe, which does not recognise it. If that is the case, then they are entitled to be part of this debate. I would like to hear your answer.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Mrs Kyenge, of course they are and have the right to take part in the debate. I would have preferred them to say things, not generalities like that, but of course they have the right. I didn't say anything else.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, this is not a 'blue card', it is a reminder of the rules. I would like to see a replay of what our colleague said. In my view, he equated the issue of discrimination, racism and homophobia with perversions. These are outrageous and unworthy statements by this European Parliament. Would you take the trouble to listen again to what he said and take the necessary sanctions, if I have correctly heard what has been said. I am not waiting for an answer, it is a reminder of the rules.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: This was not a blue card, Mr Sonierz. We are not going to play it again here, Mrs Vergiat. But I take note of your complaint. We will investigate. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their contributions which the Commission will take into account in its discussions. Let me reiterate that the Commission is committed to strengthen and make better use of all existing tools and measures to tackle discrimination, racism and intolerance, targeting people of African descent and black people in the EU.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I would like to thank all the Colleagues who have endured for so long, especially the services, and the interpreters in particular. I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
